TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At the conclusion of my statement I will table the Commonwealth's approved capital works program and honourable members will then see that this document replaces the former Budget Paper No. 12 `Civil Works Program'. It provides for the first time, at Budget time, a comprehensive statement of the Commonwealth's proposed expenditure on Budget funded capital works. The document marks a further stage in implementing the Government's decision to improve the published information relating to the Commonwealth's capital works program.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Labor Government recognises the key role of public works in the provision of social and economic infrastructure and the creation of employment; it gives high priority to maintaining expenditure on Commonwealth capital works within the constraints of a tight Budget. Publication of comprehensive information on the Commonwealth's works program is, we consider, essential for the development of the Commonwealth's policies; as a basis for appropriate consultation with other levels of government, industry and the trade union movement; and to enable government and industry to plan effectively their own activities in the current year.

The Government proposes expenditure of $1,225.7m on capital works in 1986-87. Expenditure on new works approved in this Budget is estimated at $110.1m. Some $1,115.6m will be spent on works in progress, that is, projects commenced in previous years. Of the proposed expenditure of $1,225.7m, $578.1m, or nearly half, will be allocated to my Department. A sum of $212.1m has been allocated to the civil capital works program and $296.5m to defence capital works. A sum of $69.5m has been allocated to the fitting out of leased premises. Formerly we and former governments have published only civil capital works in Budget Paper No. 12. We are now including defence and fit-out in this much more comprehensive documentation which I am tabling.

A further $216.7m over and above the $1,225.7m will be allocated to repairs and maintenance under the control of the Department of Housing and Construction. There will also be substantial expenditure by other authorities. The National Capital Development Commission and the Parliament House Construction Authority have been allocated $254.4m and $274.5m respectively. Works undertaken by or on behalf of a variety of other agencies, such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, will account for the remaining $118.6m.

The Commonwealth undertakes work to meet its requirements throughout Australia and overseas. Major projects being undertaken in 1986-87 include airport upgrading, office construction and defence facilities in Australia as well as the construction of chanceries in China and Saudi Arabia. The new Brisbane International Airport is Australia's largest ever civil aviation project. The total estimated cost is $382m. The project, which commenced in 1979-80 with extensive dredging and land reclamation works, is scheduled for substantial completion in September 1987. The people of Brisbane will be pleased about that. The estimated expenditure on this project in 1986-87 is $63m.

The biggest defence works project is the Tindal Royal Australian Air Force base near Katherine in the Northern Territory. This base will provide accommodation for the new tactical fighter, the FA18s, along with the full range of necessary base support and air defence facilities. I visited that capital works installation last week. Work at the Tindal RAAF base began in 1984-85 and the project is scheduled for completion in 1989-90. The total estimated cost is $210m. Proposed expenditure in 1986-87 is $70m with substantial expenditures still to occur from 1986-87 onwards.

Other major civil works projects currently underway include repatriation general hospital projects totalling $50m at Concord in New South Wales, Heidelberg in Victoria, Greenslopes in Queensland, and Daw Park in South Australia. New Commonwealth offices are being constructed in Adelaide and other regional cities. The Adelaide works will cost $46m. We are constructing Commonwealth law courts at Parramatta at a cost of $18m. The largest new projects approved to proceed in 1986-87 are the redevelopment of the School of Military Engineering at Casula in New South Wales, at an estimated cost of $31m, and the provision of training facilities for the Army at Swanbourne, Western Australia, at an estimated cost of $25m.

Nearly half the proposed expenditure on capital works in 1986-87 will be undertaken in the Australian Capital Territory. This reflects the Commonwealth's responsibility for functions that would be undertaken normally by State and local government in other parts of Australia, as well as the high level of expenditure on the New Parliament House. Details of individual projects with an unexpended balance of $75,000 or over are shown in the document which I will table. The document shows the estimated cost of each project, and the estimated expenditure in 1986-87. For works in progress, the unexpended balance at 30 June 1986 is also shown. It is a very comprehensive document.

Although expenditure on new capital works has had to be restrained to meet the overall need for fiscal restraint, the Commonwealth's Budget-funded capital works program will still be making a substantial contribution to the housing and construction sector in 1986-87. The total estimated expenditure of approximately $1.2 billion on Budget-funded capital works will comprise around 6 per cent of total expenditure on non-residential construction in 1986-87. Public expenditure on construction is a major source of employment. The Department of Housing and Construction has estimated that for every $1m spent on Commonwealth construction, over 20 jobs are generated in the construction sector and supplying industries. The Commonwealth's capital works program will therefore make a significant contribution to employment in the industry at a time when it is going through a period of consolidation.

Generally speaking, I turn now to the state of the industry across the public and private sectors. The non-residential building sector is reaching a plateau in activity following three years of quite strong growth. Engineering construction is still weak, though some increase is likely in contract engineering construction for private clients. The non-residential building sector has shown outstanding growth over the past three years. The recovery began in 1983-84, with a 25 per cent increase in public sector building activity. Of course, that triggered a recovery in the private sector. We have maintained buoyant private activity since then. Total non-residential building activity rose by about 10 per cent in 1983-84 and by close to 20 per cent in each of 1984-85 and 1985-86. Non-residential building activity is now at a higher level in real terms than in the boom years of the early 1970s. The main impetus has come from office building which accounts for about one-third of private sector building activity. Major office projects are underway in all capital cities. However, virtually all building types have experienced increased activity over the past two years.

The upsurge in building activity has more than offset the continuing decline in the engineering construction sector, following the end of the so-called `resources boom' of the early 1980s. As a result, total expenditure on non-residential construction has shown solid growth over the past two years. This recovery has led to strong growth in employment in the housing and construction industry. Despite the recent setback in the housing sector, which is now on the road to recovery, employment in housing and construction in May this year was at the highest level for three years. Employment in the industry rose by 70,000 to almost 490,000 in the three years to May; the three years of the Labor administration. In 1986-87 non-residential construction activity will be maintained at a high level. The upsurge in non-residential building clearly cannot and will not continue indefinitely. But forward indicators are still quite strong and a large volume of work is still in the pipeline.

During 1985-86 the value of non-residential building approvals was at a record level. Office approvals rose by 50 per cent, factory approvals by nearly 40 per cent and shops by 20 per cent. Only hotel approvals were down-by 25 per cent-compared with the previous year. I am pleased to report that private sector engineering construction is now showing some signs of recovery, underpinned by developments such as on the North West Shelf. But a further slight decline in public sector contract engineering construction seems likely in the wake of tight Budgets and restrictions on public sector borrowing. Overall, after very strong growth, the prospect is for a plateauing of activity and employment in non-residential construction in 1986-87.

I turn now to the better co-ordination procedures for Commonwealth capital works which the Federal Labor Government is already implementing and of which this document I am about to table is a component. Capital works by their nature do not fit neatly into a budget process based on annual cycles. Many projects take five years or more from design and approval stages through to completion. In addition, capital works are undertaken to meet specific needs. The level of activity, therefore, fluctuates from year to year as priorities change.

The Labor Government has been giving increasing attention to the decision-making processes associated with the development of the annual Budget. The current developments relating to Commonwealth capital works are a part of this wider improvement. The primary objective is to bring together relevant information in a timely manner to facilitate the Government's consideration of capital works programs and to provide a vehicle for post-Budget consultation with other levels of government and industry.

The document I will table provides, for the first time, a comprehensive statement at Budget time of approved Budget funded capital works, including, as I have said, defence works. This will be followed within a month or so by the publication of another edition of `Approved Commonwealth Capital Works' for public dissemination. I released publicly the first edition in March this year. This further publication will list tender target dates and the expected three-year profile of expenditure on major Budget funded works. It will provide information on approved capital works of off-Budget authorities too, together with an analysis of trends in overall expenditure on Commonwealth capital works. The first edition was warmly welcomed by the construction industry. More timely publication this year following the Budget will enhance the document's worth as a tool for planning and consultation with the private sector.

These documents are the public face of a more comprehensive information system that I have developed, in close co-operation with my ministerial colleagues, to provide improved information for Ministers in their deliberations on capital works. This will ensure that the Government has available to it timely information on the implications of proposed capital works for future Budgets and on the demands that they are likely to put on the construction industry.

As a further stage in the process, I am examining ways to improve the information and design and/or documentation associated with approval of capital works, involving referral to the Standing Committee on Public Works and return to the House and Cabinet and all that, so that we have a more orderly procedure from initial approval to Public Works Committee hearings, if they are necessary, through to final Cabinet approval.

The `Commonwealth's Approved Capital Works Program for 1986-87' underlines the Federal Labor Government's commitment to improve information relating to the Budget process, and especially to its capital works component. I believe that it is a significant step forward in the presentation of information on the Commonwealth's capital works program.
I present a copy of my statement, and I present also a copy of the `Commonwealth's Approved Capital Works Program for 1986-87'. I commend both documents to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making a copy of the statement available to me. The Opposition appreciates the high priority of maintaining expenditure on Commonwealth capital works consistent with the constraints of a tight Budget, but it feels that the Budget does not deal adequately with the curtailment of government expenditure. To achieve the current deficit level of $3.5 billion, the Government has boasted that there will be no increase in government expenditure in real terms in the current year. But we ask ourselves: What sort of an achievement is that? In the seven years of the previous coalition Government, growth in government expenditure rose in real terms by just over 2 per cent; yet in the first three years of the current Government, expenditure in real terms rose by around 7 per cent, then 6 per cent and then 3 per cent. Having increased government expenditure so sharply over the past three years, it can hardly be described as a worthwhile achievement to contain government expenditure to zero growth in real terms in the current year.

SPEECH.PARA: It is ironic that one program that is suffering a cut is the first home ownership scheme. It is ironic because the Minister has continually berated the Opposition for its proposal that funds for the first home owners scheme be consolidated with other funds and grants to the States. We know that $290m was set aside for the scheme for 1985-86, and that this year only $210m has been set aside. The Department of Local Government and Administrative Services seems to have been singled out for some kind of special treatment in the papers that the Minister has tabled. Page 21 of the Minister's portfolio programs shows that the cost of fitting out of leased premises will increase from $56.8m to $69.5m, an increase of $12.7m, or 22 per cent.

The Government has valiantly defended its iniquitous fringe benefits tax, which it has imposed on employers. One wonders to what extent we have the substitution for the fringe benefits tax by what appears to be a very significant increase in the facilities that are available to those in the public sector.

Spending on repairs and maintenance has increased also from $191m to $216.7m, a 13 per cent increase. That is hardly zero growth. We in the coalition believe that expenditure on repairs and maintenance is significantly better than the Government spending a great deal of its money on capital works. We continue to invite the Government to consider whether new Commonwealth offices, such as those in Adelaide at a cost of $46m or the law courts at Parramatta at a cost of $18m, should not be built by the private sector and then leased to the Government. If the Government is interested in saving expenditure, surely one way to do it is to lease premises rather than build them itself. This commitment to the Government taking control of everything is part of the ideological mindset that the Government has. We urge it to reconsider this approach and to ensure that more of its buildings are constructed by the private sector and leased.

We urge the Government also to get rid of its day labour force that looks after repairs and maintenance. There is no reason why the private sector should not carry out the work that is currently being undertaken by the public sector. If the Government will do this, it will save money and administration costs. We urge the Government to give consideration to cutting its expenditure by moving the bulk of the repairs and maintenance work from the public sector to the private sector.

There is an interesting item of expenditure on page 115 of the `Commonwealth's Approved Capital Works Program for 1986-87'. This item appears under the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. I refer to the new Commonwealth offices at Wollongong in New South Wales. The amount set aside last year was $17m for these Commonwealth offices at Wollongong, which I remind the House is in the heart of the Minister's electorate. This year the estimated expenditure is to be zero. One wonders whether the Minister has been spending rather more time with his faction than he has in his electorate.

The Minister's comments on the state of the industry appear to overstate the position. As we all know, the housing industry has been disastrous in the past year. It has dropped steadily from a peak and only now does it show some signs of flattening out. The health of the housing industry depends on two factors: First, the supply of money; secondly, the cost of money. Under the Government's previous policies the supply of money was drying up so quickly that it was forced to change its policies, adopt Opposition policies, lift the ceiling on housing interest loans for new loans and thus solve the money supply problem. However, the cost of money, which depends primarily on macroeconomic policies and the level of interest rates, is a matter that this Government has not yet addressed, and certainly does not address in the current Budget. Furthermore, it is clear that the Government and its own Indicative Planning Council are at odds on the number of housing starts that will occur during the 1986-87 year. The Minister acknowledges that engineering construction is still weak and in decline and that the non-residential building sector has plateaued.

General comments on the state of the industry can be seen only in the light of the forecasts for growth for the overall economy and in the light of our two most recent quarters of zero growth, and it appears that the Government's assertion of 2 1/2 per cent growth for the whole economy is overstated. Recovery in the housing and construction industry will parallel recovery in the rest of the economy, and interest rates will play a key part in that recovery. These documents are simply part of the Budget Papers, and already other Budget Papers have been shown to be inappropriate. The financial markets have reacted adversely; the business community has reacted adversely; all responsible commentators have reacted adversely; and even the Australian Council of Trade Unions is not wild about the Budget. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in his speech last night, spelt out quite clearly what is needed for the return of the long term good of the Australian economy. I spell out those six points again. Reforms must be made to reduce government spending, to reduce taxation, to reduce union power, to provide incentive for employees, to encourage overseas investments and to improve our transport and communications systems. Until this Government faces up to Australia's problem this document that the Minister has tabled today will only add to the evidence that we currently have a government that is totally unable to face up to and deal with Australia's current economic difficulties.

—On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 253rd report of the Committee entitled `Proposed computer acquisition by the Australian Audit Office', and I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Report 253 was tabled in the Senate on 12 June. At this point I wish to draw honourable members' attention to a few features of the Committee's inquiry and this report. This report was the first to be tabled by the Committee under the terms of its standing reference to investigate and report on proposed acquisitions of automatic data processing facilities by Commonwealth departments or authorities staffed under the Public Service Act 1922. The Committee received this proposal in January 1986 when Senator Walsh, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, advised the Committee that the Government had given in principle approval for the Australian Audit Office to acquire computing and communications facilities, conditional on the proposal being reviewed by the Public Accounts Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Audit Office's computer acquisition proposal involves three levels of data processing. It involves, first, a central computing facility and associated software. The AAO suggests that the central computer be an IBM compatible computer, equivalent to an IBM 4381. Secondly, the proposal involves a network to provide processing capacity, office automation and printing facilities for each State, and to provide access to the central applications. Thirdly, it involves a microcomputer facility to provide further office automation and other tools to audit staff. This proposal is estimated to involve additional expenditure over the period 1986-87 to 1989-90 of $13m, including $6m for capital equipment. The expected benefits of the proposed computer system are in the nature of improved management information, better priority determination for audits and, most importantly, an improvement in the quality of audits. The Australian Audit Office argues that the benefits to the public sector generally in terms of the greater administrative efficiency which would result from the Office's increased productive capacity are real, but immeasurable.

The Committee supports the basic motivation of AAO's proposed computer acquisition. If the AAO is to be able to conduct rigorous analyses of the performances of other departments and agencies, it must have modern management and auditing tools at its disposal. The Committee is concerned that the Australian Audit Office currently appears to be poorly equipped, at least in terms of the information technology and related expertise at its disposal, to undertake audits in some of the large and technologically sophisticated departments and agencies of the Commonwealth. However, the Committee concluded that there is some doubt whether the level of additional staff support which is to be provided for this project is sufficient to secure its successful implementation. The Committee also concluded that the Australian Audit Office has not made an adequate effort to define and quantify the benefits resulting from the proposed ADP acquisition and the information systems it will support. The Committee also considers that it is doubtful whether co-ordinating departments and agencies, including the Department of Finance and the Public Service Board, had seriously challenged or attempted to verify the benefits asserted for the Australian Audit Office's proposed ADP acquisition.

After examining the Australian Audit Office's case for restricting tenders for its mainframe computer facility to computers compatible with IBM software, the Committee concluded that the technical benefits to the Australian Audit Office in specifying that its mainframe must be IBM compatible are not persuasive, But that there are non-technical advantages in acquiring an IBM compatible mainframe facility which would be of strategic benefit to the development of the office's ADP capability. The main benefit appears to be the experience that its staff will acquire in the IBM compatible environment common to approximately two-thirds of its major auditees.

In addition to these and other conclusions specific to the Australian Audit Office case, the inquiry raises some other concerns about computer acquisitions generally. These concerns relate to the apparent difficulties of some departments in identifying and presenting a comprehensive and comprehensible statement of all costs associated with the proposal; the apparent reluctance of some departments to define and quantify the benefits which will result from the acquisition of ADP facilities; and the absence of satisfactory provisions in these proposals for the performance monitoring systems and output indicators necessary to demonstrate subsequently that these benefits are achieved. The Committee also recommended that the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services expedite its current review of the guidelines for ADP acquisition, with a commitment to issue a revised set of guidelines by the end of 1986. It also recommended that all departments and other organisations with an interest submit their comments and recommendations on the contents and operation of the guidelines to the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services and to this Committee as soon as possible. In brief, the conclusions of this report reinforce the need for greater scrutiny of ADP acquisition proposals by senior management of the acquiring department and by co-ordinating departments involved in the approval and acquisition process. The Committee's findings also emphasise the responsibilities of heads of organisations and of the Department of Finance to ensure that the performance benefits of these ADP facilities are monitored and periodically reviewed. I commend the report to honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian delegation to the seventy-fourth conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, held in Ottawa, Canada from 2 to 7 September 1985. I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian delegation to the conference comprised Senator Mal Colston as leader, myself as deputy leader, Senator Margaret Reid, Senator Sibraa, Mr Peter Baldwin and Mr Peter White. The conference was attended by more than 450 members of parliament from 94 countries. It was noteworthy that at this conference, Papua New Guinea was admitted to the membership of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. The leader of our delegation and I were pleased to be the first to congratulate the leader of the Papua New Guinea delegation, Speaker Bonga, on the admission of his country's IPU national group.

SPEECH.PARA: Whereas the United Nations is made up of representatives of governments, the IPU is made up of representatives of parliaments. In recognition of the fact that not only government but also parliaments have a large influence on the destiny of the human race, the IPU has forged close links with the United Nations. Those links were illustrated by the topics discussed at the Ottawa conference. As 1985 had been designated the International Year of Youth, it was appropriate that the conference should discuss the contribution of parliaments to the International Year of Youth with regard to the full exercise of the rights of youth to education, vocational training, work and social security and the promotion of juridical and other means of combating illicit international drug trafficking, including the preparation of a new convention by the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs. The conference adopted a constructive and far-reaching resolution on this topic. If the parliaments represented at the conference do a fraction of what was proposed in this resolution, the designation by the United Nations of 1985 as International Year of Youth will have been worth while.

As it was the 40th anniversary of the United Nations, the second topic chosen was the contribution of parliaments to terminating and consolidating the work of decolonisation started 40 years ago by the United Nations. As honourable members might guess, the debate on this topic was less harmonious than that on the first. Although a resolution was carried by a large majority, because of its lack of balance in a number of very significant areas, the resolution put to the conference was not supported by the Australian delegation.

The third item discussed at the conference related to the burden of foreign debt, particularly as it affects developing countries. Although the subject is complex and one on which many contrary views are held by the representatives of different countries, the conference was able to draft a resolution which received unanimous support.

Another feature of the conference that I found interesting was that the delegates from different countries form groupings. There is an African group, an Eastern bloc group, a non-aligned group, a group now called the 12 plus and a Nordic group. At first sight that might appear to be undesirable. On the other hand these groups bring together people with common backgrounds, common political views or common interests of some other kind.

Australia is a member of the 12 plus group. It was formerly called the 10 plus group and consisted of the 10 European countries plus Canada, the United States of America, Australia and New Zealand. That group began as a regional group. It was expanded because the regional group had within it countries that were truly democratic. Another group of countries that similarly were truly democratic and in some respects had common interests in world trade and so on was added. That group meets, as do the other groups to which I referred, and the interchange of ideas within the groups, the development of new positions and the basis of negotiations between groupings has resulted in the IPU being able to achieve agreement on issues that might not otherwise have attracted such agreement.

I mention that because sometimes it is asked whether it is worth while Australia attending such conferences. I believe that, on balance, the ability to talk to other members of parliament and find that we have common problems with other parliaments, as well as common aspirations and a common desire to reach a resolution of some of the world's most intractable problems, makes such conferences worth while.

However, there may be a need for Australia-the idea is being developed by our delegation-to look to other groupings. As I have said, the 12 plus group had its origins in Europe. There are now other democratic countries that are not members of the 12 plus group, some of which are in a region close to Australia on the Pacific rim. The Australian delegates to the Ottawa conference began a process of developing links with countries of the Pacific rim because of their regional, strategic and trade interests, and countries of that rim that are true democracies-countries where there are elected parliaments with genuine oppositions that are free to speak and free, on the fairly taken votes of the people, to become governments in their time.

There are also meetings at the IPU of members of parliament who are members of the Socialist International. There are also meetings of members of parliament whose parties are members of the International Democrat Union-the union of the conservative parties of democratic countries. That interchange, too, is valuable and is another reason why attendance at the Inter-Parliamentary Union is a worthwhile exercise for Australia.

I turn to the location of the conference in Ottawa and place on record the delegation's appreciation of the assistance provided to the delegation by the Australian High Commissioner in Ottawa at the time, Mr Laurie, and of his staff. In particular, I once again thank most sincerely, personally and on behalf of the delegation, the secretary to the delegation, Mr Tom Wharton, for his tireless efforts before the delegation left Australia, while it was away and on its return, and for all that he did to make the visit run smoothly.

I also thank the Department of Foreign Affairs adviser, whose advice was valuable and whose presence was enjoyed by all members of the delegation, for the time and effort that he put in in assisting the delegation effectively to discharge its role. The Foreign Affairs adviser to the Ottawa conference was a Mr Geoff Crawford. On behalf of all delegates, I express our thanks to him.

Finally, on a personal note, I thank all the members of the delegation for their assistance and support to me as deputy leader. I thank them in this chamber on behalf of the leader of the delegation, who I know also thanked them when tabling the report of the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed from 21 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Treasurer (Mr Keating) handed down his Budget on Tuesday, I asked myself what this Budget would do for small businessmen, the farmers, the risk takers, families, the unemployed, the needy and, most importantly, the future of the children of this great country in which the resources and opportunities are limitless. The answer was not encouraging. The Hawke-Keating Budget was directed at the international financial market which since Tuesday has been making quite clear its views and judgments. If we look at the international exchange rates we can see the way in which global judgment has been made on the `world's greatest Treasurer'. At the time the 1983-84 Budget was presented $A1 was worth US85c. There has been a depreciation of 29 per cent and at present $A1 is worth 60c to 62c in the United States. In 1983 $A1 was worth 216 yen. Since then it has depreciated a massive 54.4 per cent and now, under this Budget, $A1 is worth 95.5 yen. That is the global judgment on the world's greatest Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer to the Budget deficit in an historical context and outline what the Treasurer has presented to Australia over the last four Budgets. The 1983-84 Budget had a deficit of $7.9 billion at a time when the drought had broken and there was a surge of income; the 1984-85 Budget had a deficit of $6.6 billion; and 1985-86 the Budget had a deficit of $5.6 billion. Those three deficits totalled $20.1 billion. This year's projected Budget deficit of $3.5 billion increases that total to $23.6 billion. This explodes the myth of financial responsibility by the Treasurer. To achieve the psychological break through that the Government required in the $4 billion Budget deficit that was talked about so much in the Press, the Reserve Bank of Australia contributed $600m from windfall gains from exchange trading. Including the $600m, it contributed a total of $2.6 billion to the receipts side of the Budget. Although the Government obtained $1.4 billion in extra taxes, there has been no cutting of expenditures of any magnitude.

A pessimistic forecast in the Budget Papers indicates that inflation will remain at 8 per cent in 1986-87. Very difficult and hard comparisons must be made between our inflation rate and those of other countries. Australia has an inflation rate of 8 per cent; Japan, 0.5 per cent; the United States of America, 1.7 per cent; West Germany, minus 0.2 per cent; France, 2.3 per cent; Italy, 6.3 per cent; the United Kingdom, 2.5 per cent; and Canada, 3.7 per cent. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average is 2.6 per cent and the average of our major OECD trading partners is 2 per cent. Australia's inflation rate is still triple the OECD average, more than four times that of our major trading partners, five times that of the United States of America and more than 16 times that of our major trading partner in Japan. If we turn to the balance of payments problem, which is really at the heart of the difficulties facing Australia at this time, we find that in 1985-86 there was a deficit of $13.7 billion, or 5.5 per cent of gross domestic product. The Budget Papers indicate that there will be a further $14.5 billion deficit next year.

I draw the attention of the House to a very interesting projection in June 1986 by the stockbrokers J. B. Were and Son of Melbourne, on the commodity trade and the difficulty facing Australia in the longer term.

Australia stands alone amongst developed countries for its dependence on primary exports. A total of 80 per cent of Australia's exports are mining and rural, with little value added. The full impact of the decline in the spot price of most of our export commodities is yet to be fully reflected in the balance of payments. Therefore, we can expect the terms of trade to continue to depreciate regardless of the short term change in commodity prices. The decline in recorded export prices on the balance of payments has already been sufficient to wipe out effectively the benefit of devaluation over the last 12 months.

The report reviewed the prices of our commodities. Coal prices fell from a peak of $US55 a tonne in 1981-82 to $US42 a tonne in 1984-85. Wheat prices have fallen from a peak of $US182 a tonne in 1980-81 to $US152 a tonne in 1984-85. They are now ranging between $US130 and $US135 and are falling almost on a weekly basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will it be next year?

—It is very hard to predict what it will be next year and the year after, in view of the excess stocks in the world. Between 1981-82 and the first five months of 1986, wool prices fell by about 21 per cent in US dollar terms. The price of oil has fallen from a peak of around $US40 a barrel in 1980 to about $US14 a barrel at present. The price of Australian iron ore under long term contracts fell from a peak of $US25 a tonne in 1982 to $18 a tonne in 1984. Those figures indicate the problems facing Australian exporters and the difficulty we will have in overcoming our balance of trade problems. The internal forecast, at page 57 of Budget Paper No. 1, contains estimates that are very pessimistic indeed. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Private business fixed investment is forecast to remain weak. Improved international competitiveness and profitability should encourage investment in some areas, as should the projected easing in financial conditions. However, for 1986-87 as a whole, the recent tight financial conditions, weak commodity prices and uncertain economic prospects will be dampening influences. Investment in both plant and equipment in non residential building and construction is expected to be subdued.

That is putting it in very simple terms. The Westpac Banking Corporation review of July 1986 commented on our need to import long term capital in order to assist the inflow of capital and aid our balance of payments crisis. It made two interesting quotations in a very penetrating report. Firstly, it stated:
Fiscal and wages policy both need to be tightened if high interest rates are to be eased sufficiently . . . for firms to invest.
Secondly, it stated:
. . . it is imperative for Australia to attract large amounts of long term equity capital if its foreign debt problem is to be resolved without excessive reductions in real incomes.
The bank has indicated that to overcome our problems we need to have an inflow of equity capital or our standard of living will fall.

Turning now to the overseas debt problem, in 1983 the Hawke Government came to power with an overseas debt of about $35 billion. In the August Budget 1986, Treasury estimates the overseas debt to be in the area of $86 billion. This has come about largely because of the persistent, large current account deficits to which I have referred, the excessive expenditure by the Hawke Government, the depreciation of the Australian dollar and restrictive foreign investment guidelines which have favoured overseas borrowings rather than equity investments. To highlight the magnitude of the potential $100 billion debt that we will achieve in the next 18 months, this will represent 35 to 40 per cent of gross domestic product and will generate an annual interest bill of $9 billion or 3.5 per cent of GDP.

If we look at the situation in Victoria where the Australian Labor Party is in power, we see quite a dramatic change in that State's debt position. In 1981-82, there was a debt which had been generated over the previous 60 years of $15.8 billion. Some three years later in 1985-86 it had risen to $35 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is double.

—That is at least double, if one accounts for it accurately. The public liabilities in certain areas have changed quite remarkably. In 1981-82, semi-government authorities had liabilities of $8 billion. That rose to $18 billion. The State Insurance Office had $300,000 worth of liability; that has moved to $1.7 billion. In Victoria there was no liability for leases. But assets have been leased and now there is $1.2 billion worth of leases debt. If we reflect what the Labor States of New South Wales and South Australia have been doing, we see what sorts of debts they may have created in what they call `creative accounting'.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to interest rates, which are one of the major disincentives to investment in Australia, we see a remarkable comparison between the 18 per cent prime rate that big businesses are being charged here in Australia and the short term interest rates in our overseas trading partner countries. In West Germany the interest rate runs at about 4.4 per cent, in Japan at 4.7 per cent, in the United States of America at 5.6 per cent, in France at 7.1 per cent, and in Canada at 8.4 per cent. The short term interest rate in Australia is 17.4 per cent. So we can see that Australian businessmen are in great trouble in providing for long term investment with those sorts of interest rates.

The Budget Papers also indicate that employment rates for next year will remain high at about 8.3 per cent. The Treasurer was good enough to suggest that they might rise slightly in the next year. The coalition suggests that employment opportunities will be reduced and that unemployment will rise. The Budget Papers have put off the difficult decisions to some future time. Mention is made of the discounting of wages at the January 1987 Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearings. It is suggested that this will take place whereas it has yet to be achieved and be agreed to by the trade union movement and the Commission.

At a time of economic difficulty, the superannuation arrangements are now getting into place amongst the building industry and other industries. The Budget Papers indicate that a small section of the Australian community is taking superannuation entitlements. The coalition knows this not to be the case in times of austerity and that superannuation is being won on the ground by the trade union movement and being achieved at a rate of about 2.3 per cent. That is the first grab of superannuation claims on the longer term.

The Budget Papers suggest a growth rate of 2.25 per cent in the next 12 months. The coalition has great difficulty in establishing how this will be achieved when growth in the last two quarters has been negative.

The tax cuts have been postponed. They have now been postponed to December 1986 and July 1987. I wonder whether they will ever be achieved in the present investment and economic climate. Of course, the Budget Papers quite clearly show that there are 24 new taxes. The Government has raised $1.4 billion in extra tax measures and increases. The fringe benefits tax is in place and, likewise, the capital gains tax is in action and working.

It is an interesting comparison that the Government has seen fit to cut certain areas of activity. In my electorate of Corangamite it is proposed to close the office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is a small office with four personnel who render a very good service to western Victoria. On investigation, the Department was unable to supply me with any figures of prospective savings. I deplore the priorities of this Government when it proposes to centralise in Melbourne a section which is providing good service. The office in Melbourne will lack the capacity to serve regional Victoria.

A coalition government will disband and get rid of a number of commissions and government activities; in the longer term this will provide considerable savings. We will get rid of the Human Rights Commission, the Constitutional Commission, the Commission for the Future, the Prices Surveillance Authority and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission which will save $17m; similar State instrumentalities already execute those tasks. We will also get rid of the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the Coal Industry Council, the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes and the Foreign Investment Review Board.

Finally, this Budget will not encourage more businessmen to give jobs to some of our 600,000 unemployed people. This Budget gives no incentive to our risk takers to invest in new enterprises. This Budget does not help people to become more individually responsible for their welfare, education and health. This Budget pays no attention to the needs and aspirations of families. This Budget gives no hope for our children's future. This Budget will not lead us out of our economic disaster. This Budget is not about tomorrow; it is about yesterday and it will not even work today. This Budget will be proved to be a failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like lakes.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most important things in the Budget for the Australian Capital Territory is that the Government has given a commitment to the future of Canberra and the attempts that many of us have made to diversify the employment base. One of the great initiatives here is the increase in funding to tourism-an increase of over 70 per cent. That is particularly significant because in 1988 we shall be seeing the opening of the new Parliament House. I note that the Opposition said that it would defer that program for several years, but the building of the new Parliament House is significant in its impact on the Australian Capital Territory economy. Once the building is opened, I believe that Canberra will become much more a national capital. I believe that many more companies will establish their national headquarters here and that people from all over Australia will flock here to see their national capital. This is not just a place for 250,000 people; it is a place that belongs to all Australians and a place of which even members of the Opposition should be proud.

I also welcome the opportunity to speak on the national aspects of the Budget because this is an historic Budget which has set Australia back on the path to prosperity. This Budget has corrected the fundamentals that needed to be adjusted in the aftermath of the collapse of our export commodity prices. The major adjustments which I believe are necessary for the responsible economic management of Australia and which have been introduced by the Hawke Labor Government include a Budget deficit of $3 1/2 billion; that is, just 1.4 per cent of gross domestic product. This should well be contrasted with the deficit over which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) presided in 1982-83 and bequested to us in 1983-84.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be selective. Why not compare it with your $8 billion deficit two years ago?

—We were trying to bring down your Government's deficit; that is the problem. We were left with the burden of your years of government. One cannot slash from the extra- ordinary heights of deficit left us by the previous Government. Government spending has been held to zero real growth. Again, I contrast that with the 6.9 per cent growth for which the Leader of the Opposition was responsible in the 1982-83 Budget. This Government has taken hard decisions.
—You are kidding.

—Well, the Opposition could not tell us last night where it was going to take those decisions. The Hawke Government recognises that a depreciation induced inflationary cycle would be very damaging for the economy. We will not allow this and through our wages policy, the accord, we will continue to deliver lower wage outcomes. The Government will argue that a 2 per cent discount is necessary in the next national wage case. However, the Opposition's plan for our industrial scheme, if it has a plan, would mean chaos. It would mean that some unions would gain wage increases in excess of the 2 per cent rise we support. Others, of course, would gain nothing. Look at our record since April 1983-real labour costs have fallen by 7 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The depreciation of the Australian dollar has Australia placed at its most competitive position since the war. The opportunity to restructure our economy will never be greater. The business community must take up these opportunities. It is a great shame that we do not have bipartisan support for the efforts we are making to turn around the economy.

The significant reduction in the Budget deficit means that in 1986-87 there will be no new net bond selling program. This will ease interest rate pressures and improve incentive for investment. There is also a substantial fall in the ratio of public sector borrowing requirement to gross domestic product. This also will reduce pressure on financial markets. The Government will proceed with its planned income tax cuts. These reductions will increase incentive and boost consumer confidence. The second stage of the cuts will be introduced on 1 July 1987. We are keeping that commitment and that is part of the legislation.

These measures will support the underlying improvement in our current account deficit which is occurring. The first half of 1986 saw import values falling sharply and export values increasing. So the signs are there; improvements will come. These are difficult times, but it would be of great benefit to this country if the Opposition would stop nitpicking and provide some constructive alternatives and maybe a little bipartisan support. The fundamental underlying improvement has been masked by the collapse of our commodity prices. What has been the reaction to the Budget? Let us examine some of the editorials at the quality end of the Press. The Australian Financial Review says:
. . . economically responsible and politically honest.
The Age says:
The Budget is tough. But also, as promised, the Treasurer has done his utmost, within the constraints imposed by economic imperatives, to distribute the burdens fairly.
The Australian-even the Australian-says:
All in all, it is as good a Budget as could be expected.

For the Australian, that is a big improvement. But what happened when the Opposition's alternative Budget was presented last night? What did the Australian say about it in its editorial this morning? It said nothing-it did not get a mention. That is what the Australian thought of it. It did not think it worth while making any editorial comment. Meanwhile the Australian Financial Review this morning says:
What did the Leader of the Opposition produce? A speech which was long on rhetoric but a little short on rigorous analysis.
What did the Sydney Morning Herald say? It said that Mr Howard:

. . . failed in his Budget reply speech to solve his own credibility problem. While criticising the Government for not making deeper and more permanent spending cuts in this week's Budget, he again failed to say which government programs he would cut.

That is what the papers say about the Leader of the Opposition this morning, and it is easy to see why there are not too many smiling faces on the Opposition benches. In contrast the response from the community to the fourth Keating Budget has been very positive indeed.

Leading businessmen and business organisations have been very surprised by the effectiveness of this Budget. When they were surveyed prior to the Budget and asked what they thought the deficit should be, their responses were varied. John Elliot, from Elders IXL Ltd, said he would prefer a $3.5 billion deficit. Sir Arvi Parbo said he would prefer a $4 billion deficit with no growth in government spending. The Business Council of Australia said it would like to see no real growth in outlays with about a $4 billion deficit. What did the Budget deliver? Thanks to people like the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) who is at the table today, and who is a member of the expenditure review committee, the Budget delivered a $3.5 billion deficit, no real growth in government expenditure and major cuts in social security, health, education, defence and overseas aid. We have met-and largely bettered-the target set for us in the business and financial community. I eagerly await the commitment of these business spokespersons, like Mr Elliot and Sir Arvi Parbo, to continue to invest in Australia. It would be a great pity if political prejudice were responsible for plunging Australia into a recession.

The Government has made its contribution. We are spreading the burden as equitably as we can. Yesterday I went out to speak at a lunch for pensioners in my electorate. The message from those people to this Parliament and to the Australian people was: `We know these are tough times; we are prepared to pull in our belts for the future of Australia'. What they want is a bit of co-operation from all sectors of the community--

TALK.START.PARA: —From the trade union movement.

—The trade union movement has, in fact, been giving a fair bit of co-operation. We need that same co-operation from honourable members opposite, the business community and the community at large. We have set the foundation for the recovery of this country, and I congratulate the Government for providing this framework for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past two years country Australians have done their best to warn the Hawke Labor Government and Australians generally of the impending cost price squeeze that has been strangling the life blood out of our productive export industries. Their crisis has become our crisis-the Government's crisis. It is a national economic crisis. This Budget should have directed efforts to restoring investment and confidence in our productive industries, especially our export industries. It has failed. The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) called on Sir Arvi Parbo, John Elliot and the big corporate people to invest. The trade union movement is calling for corporate enterprises to invest. Those enterprises will not invest unless they are satisfied that the investment will be wisely based on behalf of their shareholders. It is all very well for people to say `invest, invest, invest' when the climate for investment is anything but conducive to profit. As a nation we must be singleminded about our goals-to get costs down and exports up.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget is one of lost opportunities. It is seen as such by the money markets with the dollar having fallen sharply again since the Budget. It has not redressed the mauling of the country people and it has exposed Labor's rhetoric for what it is. The Government seeks to lay the blame for our crisis on low world commodity prices. Sure, commodity prices are low, but there is little we can do to overcome that problem. However, there is much we can do to improve our own competitiveness as a nation. The Budget has failed to come to grips with the all important area of domestic production costs. Our export industries have been handicapped with near record interest rates which are at least double those of our trade competitors. This Budget will give no relief at all to the interest rate problem which is bearing heavily down on small business, on the corporate sector, the farming sector and, indeed, the employment sector. Our inflation rate is up to eight times that of our major competitors.

The wages policy has guaranteed that real increases are well beyond overseas trends and the capacity of the nation to pay. Therefore, we will continue to plunge deeper and deeper into debt as a nation. What a miserable prospect this is for young people today. What a miserable prospect for our children. What sort of a nation are we when we leave to our children a greater debt burden than past generations left us in spite of war. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talks about being in a state of war. The economy is in such a state that it is almost as if we have been at war. It is an outrage that he should try to draw such an analogy in peacetime. In 1982 the external debt was $25 billion. I repeat that figure-$25 billion. Last year the increase alone was $18 billion and it has increased now to a total of $86 billion and it is running as fast as it can towards $100 billion.

This is a high taxing Budget. Farmers in particular should not believe that they have escaped the usual severe blows this time around. Tragically, the Budget will fail to reverse those conditions which are sending the Australian living standards on an accelerating downward slide.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are plummeting.

—Yes, plummeting. In his introductory remarks, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stressed the world trade problem. He should have put his comments in perspective. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics shows an 8 per cent increase in returns for farmers against a rise of 26 per cent in costs since 1983. I repeat those figures because they are important. Cost increases have amounted to 26 per cent since 1983 as against the increase in returns of 8 per cent. It is no good just blaming world commodity prices for Australia's farm problems. The depressed world markets are not the major cause of the rural downturn. Our cost structure is a major problem. The wages policy of the Hawke Labor Government will accelerate the declining terms of trade for farmers and small businesses throughout Australia. The promised 2 per cent discount of wages for the devaluation is set against an estimated inflation rate of 8 per cent in the Budget Papers. But who believes 8 per cent? Under the wage indexation provisions of the accord, wage increases will once again outstrip those of our major trading competitors.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer makes great play of corrupted world markets but ignores the need to reduce industry input costs to give Australian export industries a fighting chance. While I acknowledge the reduction of the deficit to $3.5 billion, which has been largely achieved by increasing taxes, we need to examine the relative outlays as a percentage of the gross domestic product over the past few years. In real terms the spending in this Budget is higher than in any of the seven Fraser Government years. Amazingly, at 29.4 per cent-that is, outlays as a percentage of the GDP-it is higher than in any of the Whitlam Budgets during those disastrous years. TALK.START.PARA: —Against this background of the current deep recession, several key assumptions in the Budget Papers, including the projected inflation rate and unemployment growth, are more than questionable. Very few people in the financial world believe that the projected growth rate of slightly more than 2 per cent will be achieved or that the projected deficit can be sustained.

SPEECH.PARA: The thrust of this Budget has been to hit the community with higher taxes. The hoped for $3.5 billion deficit is based on higher revenue rather than spending cuts. Once again country Australians will, of course, be hit hardest by this Budget. The 3c a litre increase in the fuel excise will hit hardest those in country areas and remote regions. When Labor took office fuel excise was 6c a litre. Today it is nearly 24c a litre-it has quadrupled! Labor promised a 3c a litre fuel price drop in 1983. Instead it has quadrupled the fuel tax and denied the farmers and the community the full benefit of falling world oil prices. Under pressure from huge farmer rallies and the Opposition, the Hawke Government restored the fuel distillate rebate to farmers but only after having robbed them of nearly $50m over the two years for which it withdrew it. The Government refuses to acknowledge that on average farmers use 60 per cent of distillate and 40 per cent of petrol on farm. I ask honourable members to listen to this: The petrol excise now costs farmers more than $200m per annum without taking into account the increasing costs of transportation.

Labor's fuel taxes are a devastating rip-off from country Australians, the productive export industries and, indeed, all Australians. The Government's reliance on fuel tax as a major source of revenue is undermining our ability to improve our poor export performance. It is not only incredible but also totally irresponsible for any government in this country-I repeat, any government in this country-to tax fuel to the extent to which it has been taxed. Australian transportation costs represent a very significant factor in production costs generally as far as export industries are concerned. Not only are they distant from overseas markets but also, in many cases, the product is produced at a great distance from ports. Therefore, fuel represents a very significant component cost of transportation in this country. In a highly urbanised nation such as Australia this fact is sparingly understood. Indeed, it is a long-established practice to seek to suck resources from the export industries by all sorts of means. The tariff and the tax regime have been built around the export industries of this country because we have been an exporting nation. But those days are gone, and the sooner Australians recognise it the better.

With hindsight the former Government would have been wiser, when adopting import parity pricing, not to have taken the revenue windfall from the old Bass Strait oil fields and thus become so dependent upon fuel as a source of its revenue. The present Government, quite foolishly, gave up its opportunity to become less dependent on fuel as a source of revenue when the Prime Minister did his behind-closed-doors deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions behind the back of the Treasurer last year and abandoned the principle of a broad-based consumption tax. While there were problems with the Treasurer's option C, it was a far better option than the tax rag bag that we currently have. High taxes on fuel when energy resource prices are low is the worst of all worlds for a country such as Australia with its acute balance of trade problems. It is totally illogical and destructive of the export industries' competitive capacity. The reasons for this are, firstly, that low oil prices and low coal prices-indeed, low energy resource prices-cause significant reductions in Australia's export income; and secondly, that the high fuel taxes reduce the competitiveness of other export industries, such as the wheat industry, in the international market-place. It is a tragedy that this point is not being recognised by this Government at a time of our balance of trade crisis.

The dependence on fuel as a source of tax revenue is undermining Australia's ability to improve its balance of trade problems and undermining the living standards of all Australians while other countries have allowed the benefit of lower world oil prices to reduce inflation and to reduce industrial input costs. Why is it that in Japan, Germany and so many other countries, apart from having different wage regimes, their inflation rate has gone into minus figures? It is because of the lower world oil prices that have benefited those economies.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they don't have socialist governments.

—That is true. The Australian Government has gone in the opposite direction and quadrupled the fuel excise from 6c a litre to 24c a litre. It is an act of utter madness. There was never a greater need to widen the Australian tax base to get away from a tax regime that is undermining the capacity of Australian export industries to reduce the balance of trade payment problems. The Australian land transport program-the roads program-is a follow-up on the Fraser Government's move to upgrade Australia's road infrastructure.
—Who was the Minister then?

—I was the Minister then when we introduced the bicentennial road program-a very important and tremendous program. This program has been slashed while other areas of government cost saving have been overlooked. Road programs lose a further $24m on top of the $50m cut in June, and this comes on top of State Labor government allocations away from urgent country road works.

SPEECH.PARA: Another feature of the anti-rural bias is the transfer to domestic production of the fertiliser bounties currently payable on imports. Bounties were payable on both local and imported fertiliser. Through a lack of competition, this will force up the market price of imported fertiliser, some of which is not available from Australian manufacturers. This increase in the imported price will ensure that domestic prices will rise. This will increase farmers' costs-all to protect the local industry.

Let us not forget the words of the union leader, Mr O'Leary, at the height of the Prime Minister's fertiliser debacle-or the DAP debacle-in January during the Western Australian election campaign. He said it was deplorable for a Labor government to put workers on the industrial scrapheap. It is one thing to put workers on the scrapheap but another to put farmers and their families off their farms. This decision smells of a panic reaction to union pressure which will cost farmers tens of millions of dollars. Already the direct cost of protecting secondary industry alone doubles the average net farmer income of over $9,000 per annum. Departmental officers cannot see how the Budget decision can be implemented. It is an idiotic and indefensible decision and I think it is a decision that will not last, or will not stick, because it is virtually administratively impossible.

Australian producers are importers as well. Sixty per cent of our phosphate is locally produced and 40 per cent is imported. I bet that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is absolutely maddened by this stupid decision that has probably come out of the mind of some person in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce who is hell-bent on trying to protect the local fertiliser industry. I cannot understand the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) being foolish enough to come forward with such a stupid idea.

The Hawke Labor Government is thrashing farmers with another huge new protection bill simply because it lacks the political courage to set in place a bounty to protect those jobs at a cost to the community as a whole. It should not be a cost to the farmers. It makes a mockery of the superphosphate subsidy scheme.

Despite enormous pressure from outside and within Labor ranks the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax are to remain. These iniquitous taxes will be wiped out by the next Liberal-National Party government. The Treasurer may have won out this time but Labor will lose the next election, whenever that is held, if for no reason other than this stupid tax. The unfair, unjustified fringe benefits tax is seen throughout Australia as a complex, idiotic and unfair tax which will cost jobs. I ask honourable members to listen to this: Remote employers will pay $38 a week in fringe benefits tax for each employee dwelling where rent is not charged-a bill of $1,485 a year-whether or not they make a profit. This shock revelation was made on the day of the Budget. The statutory annual rent for remote area housing will be-and listen to this-$7,170 to next June, or $138 a week. The statutory rental of $138 a week is being used for the purposes of the fringe benefits tax for remote area housing. What an outrage for outback rural accommodation, outback employers and outback employees. When this amount is discounted by 40 per cent, then taxed at 46 per cent, the housing tax alone of $1,485 is the minimum valuation. The only other option is to argue the matter with the tax man at one's own cost. The unbelievable red tape and the extremely high cost to employers associated with this tax will reduce the incomes of farmers by 36 per cent.
Wine producers have once again suffered from a broken Labor promise. During the 1983 election campaign, the Minister for Primary Industry said:
Labor will not impose a sales tax or excise tax on wine.

He underlined the words `will not'. The 10 per cent sales tax imposed in the 1984 Budget will now be doubled to 20 per cent, at a time when many producers are experiencing their fourth year of negative returns. Ironically, the Government has implemented a $1.4m scheme to pull vines and, of course, this 20 per cent tax will ensure that every cent is spent. The Opposition when in government has no policies except to retain an overvalued dollar. It used it to hide our economic weaknesses.
