Now we have floated the dollar, and the money markets and out international trading relationships have shown us the weakness and the falsity of the previous Government's policy.

The successes on our domestic front have been sorely tested recently by the external pressures. I must point out that these are constraints that are not of this Government's making. This Budget recognises that the task before Government is how to face those external pressures. Those pressures are due to the collapse of the commodity markets, which has brought a decline in the prices that we receive for our coal, iron, wheat and our other major exports to the point where, instead of the long term balance of trade deficit of around $8 billion to $10 billion which was usually well covered by capital inflows so that the balance of payments well and truly squared up, the balance of trade deficit is now $13.7 billion. It is the value of the Australian dollar that has affected out external balance, not the domestic management of this economy. It will also affect our capacity to deal with that external imbalance.

I want to mention just a couple of things about the response to the readjustment of the value of the Australian dollar. This has brought out the worst in the Opposition and the sceptics. They have focused on this one economic indicator to their own political gain. I point out that the value of the Australian dollar is not a complete barometer of the integrity and the strength of our economy. It is but one indicator in a range of tried, true and trusted indicators. But the Opposition has selected this single item because it hopes to hoodwink the public into thinking that the decline in the value of the Australian dollar means a decline in the economic management of this country. That is totally false and totally wrong.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has admitted publicly that he believes his chances of becoming Prime Minister depend on the falling dollar. He goes around the country saying: `As the dollar falls, I will fall into the job'. I suggest that he will fall into a heap. The failed former Treasurer has done nothing but talk down the economy. He offers no remedies for how Australia can reconstruct. His eyes light up when the Australian dollar falls a percentage point and when Australians wince as a result. He giggles every time some smooth-tongued Ivy Leaguer American speculator comes on the television to repeat the claim that there must be more pain in Australia, that zero growth in government spending is not enough and should be further cut back and that a $3.5 billion deficit, which the Opposition said was unachievable but which scored acclaim around this country, still must be cut back further. He giggles and he is happy when foreigners are telling us how to run our country. It seems to him that democratically elected governments have no place in controlling Australia's welfare. Those who have joined in the Dutch auction on our Budget deficit and who want welfare, health and education programs cut back even more are dancing to the tune of foreign money dealers and would place us hostage to them. This is economic treason and no different from that mentioned in the Parliament the other day when reference was made to that shameful effort by a Western Australian Liberal member of parliament, Mr Lightfoot, who, too, is into bondage and pain. As a means of obtaining power, he wrote to the United States President asking him to keep up his subsidies on sugar and wheat sales. He wants to cripple our farmers so that the Liberal Party of Australia can take the sleazy road to power. That is no different from the economic reason talked by Opposition members who want to see this country ground down economically.

The Budget handed down by the Treasurer of this Government is a declaration by this Government that Australia will not be hostage to foreign money markets while this Government is in control. This Government will stay in control because the Australian people are a wake-up to the strategy of the Opposition and its paucity of any remedies to our problems. The failed former Treasurer and the Opposition are irrelevant. I will give some first hand and immediate evidence to support that claim. Anyone around Australia who had their national newspaper in their hands today, whether it was the Sun-News Pictorial, the Age, the Australian Financial Review or the Canberra Times, would have had to go to the minor pages of the paper to find any mention of what the Opposition Leader said about the Budget. Our economic journalists did not consider it worth putting one vestige, one element of his feeble contribution on to the front pages of Australia's national newspapers. Anyone who listened to the radio, to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs, would have had to wait until the fifth item in the daily broadcast of the news to hear even what the Leader of the Opposition had said: Does anyone in this Parliament need any more evidence of how irrelevant the Leader of the Opposition is considered to be in the context of having prescriptions to remedy the pressures that Australia is under on the international front.

This Budget has been appropriately cast to protect and fortify the gains made over the last three years while still coming to grips with the problems with our balance of trade. That is a tightrope act and I believe that we have the skills to bring about a rectification of our balance of trade problems and still not drive our domestic economy to the wall. The problem facing us is how to reverse our balance of trade situation. Obviously, demand for imports must be curbed in a way that cuts back consumer imports but allows for investment imports which will underpin our future manufacturing base. But at the same time we must avoid digging into and cutting back on employment. We must not increase unemployment. An improved manufacturing base will in turn be better able to provide import replacement consumer items and export oriented value added products. Those two things are essential if we are to reverse the deficit in our balance of commodity trade.

The floating of the dollar has seen Australia enjoy an increasingly improving competitive edge. As the Australian dollar falls the opportunities for our manufacturers, our exporters, increase. Yet Opposition members say that a drop in the value of the Australian dollar is wrong for Australia. The dollar is now finding its true value. Let us not argue whether the rate should be five percentage points higher or within that range. The economic realities show that it is good for Australia because there are opportunities for our exports.

In addition to floating the dollar, over the last three or four years the Australian Government has built up the domestic strength in the labour force so that full advantage can be taken of that. For instance, our prices and incomes accord-without having a federal power under the Constitution for price control, I admit that it has to be necessarily weak on that side but it represents a strong incomes policy-has resulted in real unit labour costs being reduced by 3 per cent. More importantly, the drop in the number of industrial disputes, which the Opposition always points out costs millions or billions of dollars, has meant that we have been saved that amount of money in our economy. Every time we reduce the number of industrial disputes, the number of person hours lost in our labour force, we increase the productive base, the value of our output and the cake that can be shared by Australian citizens.

Equally importantly, we have put on a long term footing a better share of gross domestic product-profitability-into our business sector. There are opportunities that must not be wasted or forgone. It is proper, correct and imperative that the Treasurer's call upon the business sector, having got the pre-conditions for doing so, to invest heavily in this country beheaded. It is not just a matter of saying: `Buy Australian'. It is also a matter of being able to say `Produce Australian' and `Sell Australian'. Not only is this true in the manufacturing sector, but the devaluation of the dollar has given a great opportunity to build up our tourism industry. Furthermore, because this Budget has reduced the public sector borrowing requirement to zero, we have provided the opportunity, without competition, of leaving the banking field and the borrowing field open for business. This is their big opportunity. The Government has said: ``We have provided the pre-conditions. It is now up to business to stand by Australia. Stop whingeing about the fact that tax equity has been restored to the tax base'. I could quote an editorial from the Australian Financial Review of a week or so ago which called on business to stop whingeing about the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax. These are not problems for industry. To seek to restore inequity to the taxation base is not the same thing as an incentive. That is where the Opposition's argument falls down. Opposition members feel that tax cheating on the rest of the community, not paying one's proper, fair share of tax, is an incentive. This Government in this Budget and over the past four years, with the advantage of the falling dollar reaching its truer level, provides the environment at the true incentive for manufacturers to get up and produce.

The consumers as a result of the Budget have been asked to take a cut in their immediate standards of living. They are being asked to cut back on consumption so that we can build for tomorrow. There is no way that we can keep consuming at the rate we have without the income to perpetuate that consumption. The fact is that on international trading account the income is not there and we have to cut back. We have to save, build up our base so that we can live properly for tomorrow. Self-denial has been spread equitably. As the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) said, there have been no cuts to pensions. There has been a six-week delay in their full indexation increase, but I repeat that there has been no reduction or cut in pensions. Recently I had a telephone call from a pensioner who said: `What is all the fuss about pensioners having to take a small cut? I am prepared to do it, and now I see in the Budget that the contribution over the whole year will be $27 per pensioner forgone on the full rate when pensioners do get indexation'. That is the maximum that is being asked of any pensioner-$27. That seems to me to be equitable when one considers that the wage and salary earners with families are being asked to forgo 2 per cent of their expected indexation increase.

The big cuts to welfare have not occurred. All the speculation, all the doom and gloom, have not come to pass. On the other hand, there have been increases in income support programs to families with young children, to those most in need. Let it not be said that this Government has turned on the traditional values of a Labor government. Let it not be said that Labor has made the most needy suffer the greatest burden. This Budget has the full stamp of equity in restraint. Those who have to cut their consumption have been asked to forgo their luxury motorcars, and they will. I consider it not only equitable and right that cars over $30,000-nearly always imported-will have a sales tax increase by 10 per cent to 30 per cent. This will give a boost to the local car industry. Apart from the competitive advantage as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar, one will see that with the distinction between a car for the ordinary family and a luxury motorcar there will be a boost in Australian production. That will mean secure employment for the wage and salary earners in the car industry to be able to bring up their families.

The tax reforms now flowing through will share the burden of taxation. The tax cuts will go ahead. Labor will honour its promise to lower marginal rates of income tax. They will be delayed for a few months. Therefore we have asked ordinary wage and salary earners to share their restraint in consumption and their burden to restore Australia's competitive position and rectify our balance of trade. More properly, the top cuts, the cuts in respect of higher salary earners, will have to wait until July next year. That is not a change. It is just to re-emphasise that there has been total equity in restraint on spending. But the Opposition, if it were to be believed, would reverse that tax reform. Opposition members boast and brag in this House that they would repeal the fringe benefits tax, a tax that has done more than anything to restore equity. I see no difference in a person's liability to tax if he gets benefits in cash or in kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the boss pays.

—The boss already takes out the income tax from the employee before he gets it. There is hardly any difference in administration and the principles behind a fringe benefits tax being paid and the employee getting a benefit measured in before-tax terms. I would point out, as I did in a speech on the fringe benefits tax, that the reason that some taxes have been avoided for 40 years has been through collusion between employers and top-paid employees. They have colluded to refrain from declaring on the income and salary statements of the employee the value of those benefits. Let us not have any statements and claims that the employers are being hard hit. They have benefited for years out of this in their collusive dealings to avoid paying into the community proper taxation payments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition seeks to abolish capital gains tax and would end the tax on lump sum superannuation which prevented double dipping and two bites at the welfare cherry. If all those promises were to be honoured, how would the Opposition reduce marginal rates of income tax? Let us remember that the tax reform which went through this Parliament in the last Budget, and which has been carried to fruition over the sessions leading up to this new Budget, has been a package. Each and every separate part of that package must be seen in relation to the others. The total tax collection in that package did not increase. There have been some minor changes which have increased the taxation take in this Budget, and we have crept one or two percentage points over our promise about the trilogy. I make no excuse for that. I do not think we should apologise. These are desperate times and we must beat our balance of payments problems. But no, the Leader of the Opposition wants to try to con the public-John the con is the expression by which he is now known.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. In the course of his Budget reply last night, the Leader of the Opposition, in making comparisons between the policy of the Labor Government and the hypothetical coalition government, said that the Prime Minister must think that the Australian disease is amnesia. Will the Prime Minister comment on the economic performance of the Government in the light of the Opposition Leader's alternative policy proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Indeed, last night in one of the most pathetic responses of any Leader of the Opposition to a Budget, the Leader of the Opposition said, as one of his many gems, that I must think that the Australian disease is amnesia. Fortunately, not all people suffer from amnesia, certainly not the convenient amnesia of the Leader of the Opposition. Very particularly, there is an important member of the Liberal Party of Australia who is currently not suffering from amnesia. I refer to something that is in a speech that will be delivered tonight by a member of the Liberal Party, a member of a former Liberal government. The speech has already been widely distributed and no doubt it will be widely reported after it is delivered tonight. I refer to a speech that will be delivered tonight by John Hyde to a branch of the Liberal Party in Western Australia. He should know what happened under the previous Government and he has been watching what has happened under this Government. What does he have to say? I share his view with honourable members. After making some criticisms of us he says in summary:

ANSWER.PARA: I now think that on balance the Hawke Labor Government has governed better than we governed.
There is no amnesia there. Just to rub it in, having said that on balance we are governing better than the Opposition governed, Mr Hyde summed it up with this:
. . . certainly better than we governed in our last 12 months.

There is no amnesia from Mr Hyde, and he is dead right. One would contrast the candour of that Western Australian with the pathetic performance of Mr Lightfoot. I wonder whether honourable members have noticed what has happened there. The Leader of the Opposition has got on to Mr Hassell and said: `Look, somehow you have to cover up this statement by a Liberal member of parliament that we want Australia to suffer.' So Mr Lightfoot under pressure wrote a letter, in which he said `Oh well, with the benefit of hindsight I really would not have said that', but the most revealing thing in his letter of contrition is this: `It was never intended for publication'. Is that not marvellous?

Let us have a look at this selective, self serving, unprincipled political chameleon who is the Leader of the Opposition. He is the convenient amnesiac of Australian politics. No wonder we never hear any more about that self-bestowed title of `Honest John'. How long is it since honourable members have heard that? It is no wonder. Let us have a look at what he said in his speech. We will see what his amnesia is like. I shall select three or four items. First, let us take tax and see what he had to say about that. In his speech he said:
Australia's taxation system must be radically reformed and simplified. There must be a substantial reduction in the marginal tax rates which have such a distinctive effect.

What did he leave as a top marginal rate when he was kicked out of office in March 1983? His legacy for the top marginal tax rate was 60c in the dollar. He had had seven and a half years in government, five years as Treasurer, to leave his mark on the marginal tax rate, but he walked out of office with that rate at 60c. Why was it at 60c? Because under his stewardship the income tax base of this country had been eroded. Why had it been eroded? Because he allowed the lurks and the perks and the avoiders to flourish. More and more burdens were imposed upon the ordinary, average Australian. That is why he walked out of office with a marginal tax rate of 60c in the dollar. Why will we be bringing in 49c in the dollar on 1 July next year? It is because we are taking away the lurks and perks. Why have we brought in a capital gains tax? Did honourable members opposite read in the Business Review Weekly last week about the 200 top income earners in Australia? What is basically the only way in which the ordinary Australian will be able to get some contribution from those people to the common revenue? It will be through this Government bringing in a capital gains tax. Because we have done that we will be able to collect revenue which will enable us to bring down the Howard 60c rate to 49c. Faced with this, what is the Leader of the Opposition going to do? He is going to take the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax away. He will give the benefits back to the 200 wealthiest people in the country and get no contribution from them. What will he do in those circumstances? He will bring in a more broadly based consumption tax, putting a greater burden on the poorest-those least able to bear it-so that he can give the benefits back to the wealthiest. He talks about tax! Let us look next at what he had to say about inflation. On page 2 of his speech he said:
This year, Australia's inflation rate will be at least 8 per cent.
What was the inflation rate that he left to this country? He left an inflation rate of 11.4 per cent. That is the difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more than enough.

—Of course it is more than enough. Honourable members opposite do not like the truth. What about unemployment? The Leader of the Opposition has had the temerity to talk about unemployment. What did he deliver in this last 12 months? 250,000 jobs disappeared and we had double digit unemployment, yet he talks about that. What does he have to say about industrial relations? He talks about improving industrial relations. What are the facts? What is the record of the previous Government's period in office? Under the Leader of the Opposition the monthly average of days lost due to industrial disputes was 248,000. That number has been reduced under this Government by more than half, to 114,000. The level of industrial disputes under the former Government was 117 per cent higher than under this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me conclude by saying that this temporary Leader of the Opposition-no wonder Andrew is smiling-the man whom this bloke told to be honest, this amnesiac, may fool some of his people but he will not fool the people of Australia, because when full memory is brought to bear they will make the same judgment that Mr Hyde has; that this Government is a significantly better government than anything honourable members opposite ever produced or ever could produce.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to page 263 of the Budget Paper No. 1 and to the estimated 6.5 per cent or $640m increase in total outlays on public debt interest. Given that this is the lowest increase in at least the past seven years, can the Treasurer tell the House of the specific-I stress the word `specific'-interest rate and exchange rate assumptions on which the estimate has been based?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not give the House that information off the top of my head but I will be quite happy to provide it. Obviously we have been arresting the increase in public debt by the Budgets we have been bringing down for three years now. The disastrous fiscal inheritance left to us by the former Government-the $9 billion deficit in prospect in 1983-84-has been reduced progressively to this figure of $3.5 billion in prospect, which is a dramatic decline in the acceleration of the Commonwealth debt obligations. It is the quantum decline in that debt which will principally diminish the growth of public debt interest in the course of the year. That is the basic assumption.

ANSWER.PARA: As we made clear in the Budget Speech, there will be no new net raisings of treasury bonds in the course of the year. Essentially, what we will be doing is funding the roll-over program from years past. Of course, there will be some net issues of treasury notes but, by and large, this Government has brought the Commonwealth Budget deficit back to the level of the late 1950s and 1960s. I observe that, in terms of bringing down the public sector borrowing requirements from 6 per cent last year, or from 8 per cent when this Government was sworn in, as a result of the former Government's policies, to a prospective 4.4 per cent this year, the great growth in State sector authorities borrowings happened when the former Treasurer and the former Prime Minister let the genie out of the bottle with their so-called infrastructure program.

The result is that the burden of bringing the public sector borrowing requirement down has been essentially a burden on the Commonwealth, because the State sector's capacity, in terms of its own recurrent budgets, to effect the aggregate borrowings of State authorities programs, is a fairly modest capacity. Therefore, the great burden of bringing down the PSBR has fallen on the Commonwealth Government and it is this Government which has tried to relieve pressures on Australian savings. Instead of having the Commonwealth Government and the States sucking up Australian savings and putting a high and very onerous burden on Australian savings, we have brought it down. It is that fiscal responsibility-none of which was displayed last evening in the Leader of the Opposition's reply to the Budget-which is curtailing the growth in public debt interest. While I could dredge up all the assumptions, it is the basic cut in the quantity of debt which is responsible for the modest growth assumed this year.

That is all it has ever been about, yet it tries to shamble around and masquerade as though it is a party of decency, interested in families and all the rest of it. The fact of the matter is that the Opposition is the same as it always has been. It will protect the ramps and rorts which it built into the tax system and it will do its best to put them back.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What is the Budget's impact on multiculturalism? Has the Government in any way altered its commitment to multicultural values?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Calwell for his question as it is an important issue. The Government, through the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and, on this occasion, through me, commits itself un- equivocally to enhancing multicultural values. Let us look quickly at what multiculturalism is. It is essentially the equality of opportunity and equality of treatment for everyone in this country from whatever cultural background they come. We are proud that people have come from some 140 different countries to this land of many cultures. We are no longer simply a reflection of any one country or culture. We have our own developing different Australian identity and everyone can feel equally part of it, whatever their background. Equality of opportunity and treatment are basic to the values of this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: People from non-English speaking backgrounds in particular need settlement help. They have to make a language adjustment when they come to this country. They need advice from social and welfare workers to assist them in making adjustments and this Labor Government has improved all these programs which especially help people of non-English speaking backgrounds individually at the grass roots.

Against that statement of principle and commitment, let me quickly address each one of the decisions we have made in the Budget which have led some people who should know better to question this commitment. Before I go to those points, let me make this point: The Leader of the Opposition has not repudiated or rejected any of the expenditure restraint decisions we have made. All he has said is that the Opposition would do more in certain areas. So there is no repudiation by the Opposition of the decisions we have taken.

First of all, I remind the Leader of the Opposition that although the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs in Melbourne is being phased out a new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs is being created within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Of course, some people would have considered it nice to have both, but every sector had to make sacrifices. Of the two bodies, the Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs will be much more effective, not just cost effective, in promoting multicultural values. The Office will be located in Canberra.

Frankly, the Institute, although vastly improved by us over the past year, had found the job of making an impact on Australia and in society an impossible one. It would seem to be of Melbourne but not for all Australia.

The merging of the Special Broadcasting Service and the Australian Broadcasting Commission will have two major results. It will give security at last to our unique multicultural radio and television. The SBS will influence that other arm of operations, the ABC, into realising that we are no longer just an Anglo-Celt culture. The former insecurity of the SBS was worrying.

I shall address myself to the education of our kids, our children of non-English speaking background. I am bound to remind honourable members that the education of our young is basically a State responsibility, and the States guard it jealously. The Commonwealth programs, as you would appreciate, Madam Speaker, have largely been seed programs and have prodded the States into directions which were being neglected.

With that as the background, let me state that our ethnic schools program has been maintained. We cannot promise growth this year-the 20 per cent growth of the past two years could not continue. The multicultural studies program was small and fragmented. It has sown its seed and it must be absorbed into Australian studies. At the Commonwealth level we shall use all our influence for that to be done, which is the way in which multicultural values should be taught.
English as a second language-that is, the ESL program for non-English speaking children-has recently arrived. It is being maintained as before.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been halved.

—The honourable gentleman says that it has been halved. I remind him that the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable gentleman's Leader for the time being, has endorsed what we have done. If the honourable gentleman has any attack to make upon that, let him attack his Leader.

ANSWER.PARA: English as a second language, in the form of supplementary teaching of English to children who have been here for some time, must be taken on by the States as a basic part of our education system. Here, too, we have sown the seeds. We are still contributing specific help to the extent of the large sum of $34m in 1987. General grants to the States for education have increased and resource agreements will establish the priorities. Teaching all children to be proficient in English must be subject to those resource agreements. The report on the quality of education by Professor Karmel questioned the effectiveness of the existing ESL program. We hope that these changes will lead to improvements. The long-awaited national language policy is almost finalised, and funds here have been allocated in the Budget for its implementation.

It is crystal clear that we have a continuing commitment to multicultural values. At the grass roots, where it matters, Labor is putting into effect increased efforts. At a time of stringency we are nevertheless increasing the resources for the teaching of English to adults through our Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs adult migration program. We have more grants-in-aid to finance social workers for ethnic communities to aid the settlement of their people.

The Government's commitment to multicultural Australia is stronger than ever. I repeat that the decisions that we have had to take for economic purposes have been endorsed and not repudiated by the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: I must point out to the honourable member that it is utter hypocrisy for any Opposition member to criticise such a decision, particularly in view of the sort of speech that we had from the Leader of the Opposition last night, when he suggested that the cuts that have taken place to date should have been greater.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of calls for a wage freeze? Could the Minister tell the Parliament how such an outcome could be achieved through a system of decentralised wage fixing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of calls by the Leader of the Opposition for the Government to implement a wage freeze. The honourable gentleman made that call in his speech when replying to the Budget last night. Subsequent to that he elaborated on the matter when he was interviewed on the Carleton-Walsh Report. He said then that he would not seek to impose a wage freeze if he were in government. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I'm advocating a wage freeze in the context of us having a centralised system at the present time. I mean, I'm saying to the government . . . you try and get a wage freeze, I mean you want a centralised system. You make that centralised system work and deliver a wage freeze. Obviously if we were in power and we started to change towards a less regulated system, then the parameters in which we'd operate would be different.

In other words, he is saying that the Government should implement a wage freeze, but if he were in government he would not pursue one. He would not pursue one because he supports a deregulated wages system, which would mean that he could not implement a wage freeze.

What an absurd situation the Opposition is in. It is saying to the nation-it did so in the speech that was delivered on television last night-that what this country needs is a wage freeze. The Leader of the Opposition gets on television after that speech and says: `But if I were the Prime Minister of this country, you would not have one because we would have a deregulated wages system'. What a ridiculous policy that is. What an absurd wages policy that is for the Opposition to portray to the nation as some sort of responsible response to the Government's Budget.

This question is also raised: What would be the outcome of a deregulated wages system? There is every reason to believe that such a system would result in much higher wage outcomes than those presently occurring and it should be realised that these are producing a reduction in real wages, and that we have had these reductions over the past three years. That is not something which has been easily obtained, but it has been obtained in a consensus arrangement with the trade union movement. It defies the imagination of anyone to believe that that could have been achieved by any other system, with concurrent strong employment growth.

Let us look back at our history. In 1981 and 1982 we saw what happened when a centralised system ended and there was open slather. We had a 16.5 per cent wage increase in 1982 when our trading partners had 6.5 per cent. If we look at other countries and draw comparisons that are based on their experience, we should consider countries which have similar union situations, in the sense of the proportion of the work force in unions and with similar union structures. The obvious countries to look at are New Zealand and the United Kingdom. If one looks at what is happening there, one sees that New Zealand wages increased last year by 12 1/2 per cent, the United Kingdom by 7 1/2 per cent and Australia by just over 6 per cent. So with the deregulated wages system operating in these countries with similar union structures, higher wages outcomes occur than in Australia with a centralised system applying. All that is happening in the United Kingdom with a 13 per cent unemployment rate.

I think it should be understood that, in the United Kingdom, a resort to increased unemployment to control wages has still resulted in strong increases in real wages, and that is a matter which the Thatcher Government is simply incapable of controlling. When I was in the United Kingdom a couple of months ago I spoke with the Secretary of State for Employment, Lord Young, about this particular problem of the growth in wages in the United Kingdom and Lord Young agreed that the United Kingdom had a great problem with the continuing high real wage growth, despite strong unemployment. When I asked him what his Government was doing about it he said: `We are making speeches'. That is all that the Opposition would be doing if it was in government operating a deregulated wages system and trying to control the wage outcome. Honourable members opposite would be standing here saying how irresponsible the unions were, making great passionate anti-union speeches, and watching wages go through the roof. That would be the outcome. There is no doubt that the absurdity of a deregulated flexible system that the Opposition is portraying would result in a much worse wage outcome than we have had in this country.

We do not need a wage freeze in this country. We do not need, either, a flexible wages blow-out. What we need in this country are responsible wage outcomes of the kind that we have been getting, which have enabled us to have a strong growth in the economy for three years, and which are assisting now to get us through the period of strong adjustment that we need to go through because of the balance of payments situation. That is the wages system which is appropriate to this country and it will continue to produce the goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry would be aware that his Department will spend $5.3m on a vine-pull scheme for wine grapes this year. The Government in this Budget has imposed a 20 per cent sales tax on wine which may force many more producers into the vine-pull scheme. Does he not agree that there is some inconsistency with a government that pays people to get out of an industry but at the same time taxes people out of that same industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be amazed if for once the Opposition did not come up with the most simplistic case put to it on any industry matter by the industry lobby. I would be absolutely amazed if it came up with any original or lateral thinking on any issue of agricultural policy.
—Stop whining.

—Oh, here we are-the last of the `babble-onians'. If the honourable member had some understanding of the wine industry he would realise that it is not the least bit inconsistent to have a vine-pull scheme at the same time as some measure of taxation is being levied on this industry. The simple fact is that the biggest problem for the industry is always the potential wine lake which comes from the multi-purpose grape growing areas. The second major problem for the wine industry in terms of the grape growers, whom I take it the honourable member is representing, as well as wine makers, is the fact that we have a structure of farms in the irrigation areas that goes back to the size of blocks in farmer settlement schemes. The problems of reconstruction in those areas are very difficult indeed. That is why there is no inconsistency.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that there is quite a bit of concern about two items that affect my portfolio, even though I suppose, technically, they relate to taxation matters and therefore to the Treasurer's responsibility. But I am sure he would say, as I do, that the big problem in the wine industry is really overproduction and the industry's structure. One of the ways out of this, given that we have a massive devaluation, is for there to be more exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about imports?

—But the big problem there is that the industry is failing to get its act together and we have had a great brawl within the industry whereby the major producers of wine have been trying to defeat efforts by smaller premium wine makers to get more heavily into the business of export promotion. We are making some breakthroughs on wine exports, but there is enormous potential there. An honourable gentleman interjected and asked: `What about imports?' Here again, I must say, there is a fair amount of frustration in getting this industry to get its act together. We have been trying to get uniform food Acts so that we can at least look at the imports of wine which does meet our standards, because in terms of doing unto others as they do unto us, the Europeans take us to the cleaners. But, of course, one cannot get all the States to agree. My colleague the Minister for Health has been trying to get uniform food Acts, and due to his assiduous approach to this task we are now some way towards getting some resolution of a uniform food Act among the States so that we can look at this aspect of imports. But lo and behold, when one looks at that matter in a bit more detail, when one starts to look at the standards for our Australian wine, again we find that the industry has not got its own act together.

ANSWER.PARA: I could talk a lot more about citrus products and a few other products that are affected by exports and imports as well, but I will not take the time of the House, except to say that in respect of the citrus industry I do not think that the 10 per cent tax will have any effect in terms of consumption beyond the existing problem. One thing I failed to mention on exports is that there is potential for exports of sultanas and Thompson seedless grapes, and if we can work and get our act together we will remove some of that potential wine lake. Yesterday I had in my office some exporters from the citrus industry who said that they simply could not get the amount of quality fruit that they wanted. That is not necessarily a criticism of the industry. It will take time to get its act together. But the industry is selling citrus products; one can get prices of about $280 a tonne for it while producers are lucky to get $80 a tonne at present. The delegation put to me that the black spots in the area were packing, growing and the problem of shipping. The problem of shipping is something which the Minister for Transport and I are addressing, but it does not simply involve blaming the unions for the problems of shipping; the problem relates to the fact that we are ineffective at co-ordination and delivery and that we are always seeking to blame other people when, with a bit of work, we could do a lot to take advantage of the devaluation and help these industries out rather than bleating with some simplistic argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer advise the House how the Federal Government's Budget would have been affected were the proposals put forward by the Leader of the Opposition last night to be adopted by the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have a disastrous impact on fiscal policy because rarely has the Parliament been treated to a sleight of hand like it was treated to last night by the Leader of the Opposition in suggesting that he had cut back his spending promises. What he really did say was that he would not cut back his receipts and taxation promises. He used a throw-away line like that in a speech which junks promises, and he has been currying favour around the countryside particularly with members of the National Party of Australia. He has made promises which he has no intention of keeping. He made massive promises on the receipts side, which he did not mention in his speech and which he does not attempt to reconcile in his adoption of an alternative fiscal policy. It is almost unbelievable.

ANSWER.PARA: That somebody who has held the position of Treasurer of this country can make the traditional reply speech of the Leader of the Opposition to the Budget yet have an $11 billion credibility problem in terms of commitments on the receipts side of the Commonwealth ledger and not refer to them, not try to reconcile this position with the Commonwealth Government's position, and not try to say how fiscal policy would be under a coalition administration, is simply to treat the Parliament foolishly and the public even more so. The credibility which the Leader of the Opposition had yesterday he still has today. Let me recount for a second the commitments which stand on receipts in respect of the Opposition's approach: Institute income splitting, $2.7 billion; a flatter tax system by dropping the 49c rate to a 40c rate for companies and individuals from 1 July 1987, $1.6 billion; abolish the fringe benefits tax, $325m; abolish the capital gains tax, $5m; abolish the tax on lump sum superannuation, $80m; reinstitute entertainment expenses, $310m; reinstitute negative gearing, $50m; full flow-on of world oil price reductions, $400m; abolish the sales tax on oils and lubricants, $66m; abolish the tax on new oil, $165m; provide child care rebates, $108m; restore income equalisation deposits and in-out tax averaging $23m; and abolish the wine tax, $107m. That makes a total of $5.9 billion.

The Leader of the Opposition says that he would bring the Budget deficit to zero, not by lifting receipts but by reducing receipts, but he would still have to fund the following commitments: The abolition of the assets test, which would cost $150m; the wage freeze which he says he will have, which would cost $400m; and opting out of Medicare-that is, the healthy can opt out, leaving the sick and the pensioners behind-which would cost $900m. The $3.5 billion of the deficit, the $5.9 billion of the tax receipts, letting people opt out of Medicare, abolishing the assets test and a wage freeze comes to $11 billion, yet no attempt was made by the Opposition to try to reconcile these statements.

I notice that whenever some hard data is thrown at the Opposition one of the Leader of the Opposition's deputies springs to attention to have a conversation. This is one of the Opposition's techniques. The reason for this is that the Leader of the Opposition has no heart for any hard message. He has a heart like a split pea. One of the reasons why he could get nothing through the Cabinet between 1977 and 1982 was that caraway seed that ticks over in his chest, the same one in evidence now, which makes him turn his back whenever a hard answer is directed towards him. The hard answer is that he has a $5.9 billion credibility gap on tax, a $3.5 billion credibility gap on the deficit and an $11 billion credibility gap in total, none of which he mentioned last night in his speech as Leader of the Opposition.

The contemptible speech even contained clauses and sentences cut straight out from other speeches over the last few weeks. The speech was put together on the run by an Opposition on the run. But this was the new Opposition that was going to come back invigorated from the Liberal Party Council meeting and do the Government over. Let me say at the end of the first week that if that is the medicine the Government is going to get, the Opposition will be there for a long time. The Opposition can try to kid the people by saying that it will cut this, that and something else out, but, as my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations said, while the Opposition keep up antics such as saying to the Government, `You have had a wage freeze, but we will not have one', it will stay right where it belongs-firmly rooted in opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the following reports which have been circulated to all honourable members: Ownership and Control of Commercial Television and the Equalisation of Regional Commercial Television Draft Indicative Plan. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to report progress on several inter-related projects which contribute towards the Government's goal of providing broadcasting services in most regional areas comparable to those in the capital cities; that is, equalisation. As I said in my last ministerial statement, Regional Commercial Television in Australia, on 20 May 1986, equalisation is well within our reach. We have also initiated a series of studies designed to foreshadow the main milestones for the commercial sector of the broadcasting system in the next 10 years. I can report today that three important studies are now available:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) Ownership and Control of Commercial Television;
(b) Equalisation of Regional Commercial Television: Draft Indicative Plan; and
(c) Future Directions for commercial Radio.
Anyone interested in the future of broadcasting will have ample material for analysis and comment in these three documents.
Ownership and Control of Commercial Television

On 28 August 1985 I announced that the Forward Development Unit-FDU-of my Department would make a study of the ownership and control rules applying to commercial television stations, in order to identify options for change. I directed the FDU to consult with the broadcasting industry, unions, consumer groups and other interested organisations and to concentrate upon:
(a) evaluating the current ownership and/or control system in terms of its effectiveness in achieving the Government's policy objectives;
(b) identifying the principles which should underlie any new system of ownership and/or control;
(c) developing alternative proposals, including draft guidelines for amendments to the broadcasting legislation.
As usual, the FDU was not to make recommendations, but to provide background and to identify issues and options.

The ownership and control regime incorporated in the Broadcasting Act 1942 is a complex net of inter-related provisions forged essentially in the 1950s and 1960s. The FDU study has confirmed that they are no longer adequate and are badly in need of updating. Indeed, it agrees with one learned judge in labelling them as `labyrinthine and tortuous'.
Among the many specifics in the report, the FDU identified five `key principles' advanced by past Ministers, regulatory authorities and committees of inquiry as underpinning the regulations:
(a) to avoid undue concentration of ownership or control of commercial television;
(b) to promote local ownership and favour `independent' applicants;
(c) to limit foreign ownership and prohibit foreign control;
(d) to preserve the integrity of licensing decisions; and
(e) to encourage a diverse shareholding in licensee companies.

It also noted that the issue of `cross-media ownership' had been given considerable prominence during licence inquiries. Whatever their merits when first advanced, the FDU suggests that two of these five `key principles' are no longer attainable. In the case of local ownership, as early as 1984 Mr James Oswin's localism report examined nine regional television stations and found that seven of the nine already had less than 25 per cent local shareholding, while only one was more than 50 per cent locally owned.

In the case of diversity in television shareholdings, the FDU found that if the interests of parent companies and subsidiaries are taken into account, 27 of the 50 licensee companies are 100 per cent owned and 40 have a major shareholder with 50 per cent or more of their shares. Another four have a major shareholder with 45 to 49.99 per cent of their shares. Put simply, in only six licensee companies is there any spread of shareholding. Moreover, these are companies with licences for the smaller stations, each serving not more than 1 per cent of the Australian population.

The other three principles remain highly relevant but would benefit from restatement. This applies particularly to the principles regarding undue concentration of ownership and control, foreign ownership and control and preserving the integrity of licensing decisions.

Having studied ownership patterns in detail, the study confirmed a pattern of consolidation of ownership within licensee companies. It noted that, at 31 December 1985, 22 persons held prescribed interests in two licences, that is, they hold two licences, or control two licences, or have more than 5 per cent control shares in two licences.

It also noted that there was extensive cross-ownership between commercial television and other media. In 22 markets, at least one person holds a direct prescribed interest in both the local television licence and a local radio licence. When ownership of print media is also taken into account, it is evident that there is substantial cross-media ownership at the local level.

There is also extensive cross-media ownership at national level. The four largest media groups, Herald and Weekly Times, Fairfax, News Corporation and Consolidated Press, have very extensive holdings in television, radio and newspapers.
The FDU noted the Australian Labor Party Federal platform, which includes a plank: `Limit the degree of cross-media ownership currently existing in Australia'.

Currently the ownership and control rules capture literally hundreds of persons who have no ability to affect programming decisions in any way, yet considerable resources are consumed in registering their interests. The study suggests that it might be more sensible to define `system objectives' in the legislation. `Ownership', `control' and `influence' are all elusive concepts and it would be logical to relate the rules to persons who are able to affect the outputs-the services and programs produced by the broadcasting system.

Of course, there is a great deal more in the report. It appears in two substantial volumes and will be a source document for many years to come for anyone interested in the media. My specific purpose today is to table the report. My Department will organise a seminar for interested parties early next year and I will accept submissions regarding ownership and control matters generally until 31 March 1987.

One final word on this subject. My Department published the FDU's first report, `Future Directions for Commercial Television', in June 1985. That report identified various approaches to revising the `two station rule'. The present FDU report takes up the same theme, observing that there are two broad approaches to replacing the current rule: Firstly, express the limit in terms of the holding of prescribed interests in commercial television licences which together reach a specified proportion of the Australian population. Secondly, establish numerical limits for designated categories of licence. That is, there is general agreement that a new rule should reflect the audience of stations, but the actual formula to be set has not yet been decided. It has been extensively discussed, and in May this year the Government decided to address the questions of the `two station rule' by 31 October 1986.
Equalisation of Regional Commercial Television

Having considered the FDU's report, in December 1985 the Government established a committee of Ministers, consisting of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and myself, to review a number of key questions concerning equalisation of regional commercial television. A task force consisting of officers from the relevant departments and chaired by Mr Charles Halton provided advice to the committee. On 12 May 1986, the Government made a series of decisions which were reflected in my statement of 20 May. As a consequence, in June, I established a small group of planners in my Department to prepare a draft indicative plan, that is, a plan setting out the Government's intentions regarding the aggregation of television markets. This has now been published under the title of `Equalisation of Regional Commercial Television: Draft Indicative Plan'.

Since the draft plan has been given extensive publicity, I do not propose to elaborate too much here. However, it may be useful if I remind the House of the main points. Basically, it identifies the planning criteria to be applied in moving towards equalisation as community of interest, viability, contiguity and avoiding overlap of time zones or State borders. On the basis of these criteria, it proposes approved markets, known as AMs, in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. It also proposes three potential AMs in South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania and three remote areas-Mount Isa, Broken Hill and Darwin. These remote areas were judged to be too small at this time to support three competitive services. Since in South Australia and Western Australia the only way to achieve three competitive services would be to include the State capitals in approved markets, and this involves too many owners, the draft plan recommends that regional licensees in those States be allowed to take the interim step of multi-channel services; that is, licensees will be able to provide a second, or a third, service in their existing markets. It proposes that the situation be reviewed after likely changes to the ownership and control rules. Because of its relatively small size as a market, its isolation and its current ownership pattern, the draft plan treats Tasmania as a special case. It proposes to provide two competitive services by inviting applications for a new licence covering both the Hobart and Launceston service areas. This also will be subject to review by the Minister.

Honourable members may know that the draft plan provides detailed technical, socio-economic and financial material required to make planning decisions for all regional areas in Australia. This is the first time such material has ever been available and it too should prove to be a valuable source document for some time. However, I want to stress that the draft plan is just that-a draft plan. I have already noted the arguments of Regional Television Australia, which represents regional licensees, that aggregated markets need populations of about one million if three competitive services are to survive. The effect of this approach would be to have only four approved markets-one in Queensland, two in New South Wales and one in Victoria. I have also received some early submissions from individual licensees. For example, the licensees from Ballarat/Shepparton, Bendigo/Traralgon and Hobart/Launceston suggest that the regional areas of Victoria and Tasmania should be combined into one approved market so that they will have a larger and richer advertising base from which to operate.

We have not yet decided anything regarding the final indicative plan. However, I should comment that some of these early submissions appear to be more concerned with the interests of licensees than the interests of viewers. My response to such submissions has been to draw attention to the planning criteria and to point out that the Government is planning in the public interest. While viability of the system is an important planning criterion, guaranteeing a high level of profits for existing licensees emphatically is not. It will be seen that the Government has not changed the deadlines for its implementation of equalisation. We still expect services in main centres by 1988 and services in lesser centres by 1990. Submissions regarding the draft indicative plan close on 17 September 1986.
Future Directions for Commercial Radio

The last of the three studies is about radio rather than television. In February 1985, I directed the FDU to undertake a study of future directions for commercial broadcasting in Australia. Among other things, I asked it to identify options leading to `adequate commercial radio services to all communities'. Later the same year I defined `adequate' to mean `as soon as practical, make available at least one additional commercial radio service to communities outside mainland State capital cities'. Inevitably, the planners have dubbed this the `additional services policy'.

In February 1986, after representations from the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, I directed the FDU to produce an interim report regarding the question of converting existing commercial AM services to the FM band. This they did and the report was published in March 1986. While there are many logical possibilities, the report found that only three options were worth discussing:
Option 1: Allow all commercial stations to convert
Option 2: Allow regional commercial stations in competition with an FM station to convert
Option 3: Allow no conversion.
There are, of course, partial versions of any of these as well.

The present report, which is entitled `Future Directions for Commercial Radio', should be read in conjunction with the interim report. Basically, it suggests that the Minister for Communications should categorise markets into four groups:
Group A-markets where the Minister finds a prima facie case that a new competing licence would be viable;
Group B-markets where the Minister feels that it is not possible to decide without further data;
Group C-markets where the Minister is satisfied that a new, competing licence would not be viable; and
Group D-markets so isolated and or small that special measures must be taken.
Once this categorisation has been done, the FDU suggests three options for delivering additional services:
Option 1: Status quo would use the existing supplementary licence scheme and ministerial planning powers, but vary their application according to the category of market concerned.
Option 2: Compromise would allow for automatic grant of supplementary licences in Group C markets, that is, those where a new licence is not viable.

Option 3: `Fast-track' would amend the legislation to abolish the existing supplementary licence scheme and allow for the granting of permits to existing licensees to provide a second service in Group C markets.

It should be noted that, under any of these options, as Minister for Communications I would immediately invite applications for the grant of commercial radio licences in appropriate Group A markets. These additional licences would not necessarily have the same service area as existing licences, but could be based on urban centres or such existing entities as television Service Areas. While progress with planning proposals will, of course, be subject to resource constraints, this is perhaps the most important single section because it suggests a means of breaking the log-jam in planning for additional radio services and allowing aspiring licensees to put their case before public inquiries.
Other matters of interest covered in the report are ownership and control, program regulation, localism and viability.

The FDU scouts three areas of change regarding ownership and control rules for radio. It looks at options for raising or removing the national limit of eight licences per person and suggests that the one-to-a-market rule will have to be extended to regional areas, as in television; that is, it would not be possible for a person to own or control two commercial stations in the same market. The report also flags the possibility of removing some rules regarding radio altogether.

In the area of programming, it observes that introduction of one additional station in regional markets will not necessarily provide diversity of choice to country listeners. Many people argue that licensees, intent on maximising their ratings, will indulge in `me-tooism'-the practice of duplicating their rival's programs so that both stations aim at exactly the same segment of the audience. The FDU does not agree that this is inevitable. However, it suggests that such a development would lead to complaints from listeners and identifies some options for program regulation if the Government felt that licensees were not using their stations to provide diversity of choice.

One of its more depressing conclusions is that although listeners strongly support local content in programming, and this is used by existing licensees to argue for the status quo, any battle to protect local ownership of commercial radio stations has long since been lost. In 1983 75 per cent of regional stations in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory were less than 25 per cent locally owned. By 1984, 85 per cent of the 33 regional stations surveyed throughout Australia were less than 25 per cent locally-owned.

Finally, the FDU discusses the contentious issue of viability. This concept is central to the licensing provisions of the Broadcasting Act 1942 and has been the focus of a good deal of critical attention. Having regard to the Government's interest in making the broadcasting industry competitive, the FDU observes that a review of the concept would highlight the conservative and protectionist effects of having viability entrenched in the legislation. It also identifies a series of difficult issues which need to be addressed in such a review, including the functions to be performed by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

The interim report on AM:FM conversion has been freely available since March and the final report, `Future Directions for Commercial Radio', will be in Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops from 5 September. Submissions regarding both reports close on 30 November 1986.
Conclusion

Broadcasters, investors and interested members of the public who study the four FDU reports and the draft indicative plan will recognise that they set the agenda for debate on the broadcasting industry. In exercising my responsibility under the Broadcasting Act 1942 `to plan the development of broadcasting services in Australia', I will be greatly helped by their existence. They do not prescribe policy; nor do they provide all the answers. That is the job of the Government. But they contain an immensely useful body of data about the industry which has not been systematically assembled before and they do flag the significant issues. They will be an essential point of departure for discussions about broadcasting during the next decade.

Finally, I should not let the occasion pass without conveying my personal gratitude to the small band of officials in the FDU and the Indicative Planning Group, who have produced these reports. At a time when resources are very tight, it is all too easy for people outside government to imagine that the solution to our problems might be to attack waste and inefficiency in the public sector. As the Budget Speech has made abundantly clear, we have no reservations about examining Government spending and making hard decisions as a result, but it should not be forgotten that the best people in the Public Service are very good indeed. As the preparation and publication of these reports over a period of just 18 months demonstrates, they can also be very hard-working and productive.
