Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs to Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners.
2. That the impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2 burden with the purchase of each pharmaceutical benefit scheme drug.

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb and Mr Halverson.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs to Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Ms Jakobsen.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and the present justice system in this country or in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Hicks.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of average weekly earnings;
2. that the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards and Mr Nehl.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing-related Poverty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of citizens of Australia shows that-
Approximately 100,000 Australians live on the verge of homelessness, dependent on Government resources to survive, or sleep out of doors or in refuges.
Over 700,000 households, or in excess of 2 million Australians are living below the poverty line after paying their rent or mortgage costs.
In addition, there are thousands of households with special needs, such as the disabled, who are not well catered for in the private sector but who nevertheless require suitable housing.
Waiting lists for public housing have almost doubled in the past five years to 146,000 by June 1985. The list is expected to grow to some 250,000 by 1990.
We therefore ask that the Australian Government, as a highest priority.
Undertake a campaign to bring the issue of poverty and, in particular, housing-related poverty, to the attention of the Australian public.
Increase expenditure on public housing through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, by at least 15% annually in real terms.
Increase rent relief payments for those on low incomes in the private rental market.
Use its influence with State and Territory governments to encourage them to increase their expenditures on public housing.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Fatin and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
In this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a nuclear test moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers.
That such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
That such a moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would:
Be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament.
Impede the development of new nuclear weapons.
Decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy.
Inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to:
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hand and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; and, to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards-
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilizing nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government-(a) take new initiatives to incourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the Governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time, (b) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal Members of Parliament and Senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986/87 budget.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hollis and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth the legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you do not proceed with the legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations:
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their remuneration packages:
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small businesses:
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Islander Languages
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
(a) Aboriginal and Islander languages, which numbered approximately 260 when Europeans first arrived, are even more seriously endangered-already 145 have become extinct.
(b) English-speaking population expansion and English-speaking mass media expansion threatens the survival of the remaining languages of Australia.

(c) Aboriginal languages reflect an ethos that is truly Australian and unless steps are taken to implement language maintenance, this ethos will be lost not only to Aborigines but to non-Aboriginal Australians, and to the world.
We humbly pray the Government to:

1. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide $300,000 per annum for a guaranteed period of ten years to enable the Aboriginal community of Australia to establish a co-ordinating body to implement steps to prevent the extinction of the remaining languages, and to introduce programmes which will enable these languages to continue into the future for the sake of all Australians. This body will enable us to maximise existing financial, material, and human resources, and is the least expensive way of implementing urgently needed maintenance programmes.
2. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide finance for the establishment of Regional Language Centres-ten are urgently needed-cost $200,000 each.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

We, the undersigned petitioners, call upon the Australian Parliament to set up strong national Aboriginal land-rights legislation. We call upon Parliament to establish this legislation in line with the five principles of ALP Party Policy and to use its powers to over-ride states which do not comply with the legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Wyong, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the lack of a Medicare Office in Wyong is seriously inconveniencing the residents of Wyong Shire.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare Office is established in Wyong as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully sheweth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that:
The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully sheweth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that:
The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lucas Heights Nuclear Reactor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the wake of the Chernobyl reactor disaster, no nuclear reactor can be considered entirely safe. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government close down the Lucas Heights reactor immediately and permanently.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lucas Heights Nuclear Reactor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the wake of the Chernobyl reactor disaster, no nuclear reactor can be considered entirely safe. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government close down the Lucas Heights reactor immediately and that no new nuclear reactors be built within Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors;
2. its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes;
3. its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance;

4. in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That whereas the Federal Government has imposed the Fringe Benefits Tax, such a tax will increase inflationary pressures, lead to a net loss in employment, will add significant cost and time burdens to business in this country and is in every sense an inequitable taxation measure.
The following people in the state of Tasmania therefore urge the Federal Parliament to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits.

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable.
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marsfield Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Marsfield be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal and banking requirements, or even to collect registered, certified letters and parcels. Many of us are pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Offices are about 2kms away with no convenient public transport. Also for those of us who work during the week, this is the only Post Office open on Saturday mornings where we can collect our parcels, do our mailing and other services it provides.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that The House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Marsfield Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:
Woodchipping and clear-felling will destroy the Otway forests, water catchments and jobs in tourism.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will protect the Otway forests for the future and refuse any licence to export woodchips from the Otways.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia, electors of the Division of Calare shows-
The proposed gold tax will severely affect the livelihood of numerous people involved in the exploration, mining and service divisions of the gold mining industry in this district.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the proposed gold tax not be introduced.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's proposal to bring about a reduction in the amount payable under the present Family Allowance Scheme, that the House of Representatives assembled oppose such a move, on the evidence of its impact upon the family unit.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek to restore payments to the former level.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant products to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
Take the action necessary to create an Australian Republic on or before 1st January 1988.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the hardship which will be caused to these citizens as a consequence of proposed cuts in Social Security Benefits being initiated in the Budget to be brought down on August 19, 1986.
Your petitioners therefore pray and request the Government not to attack the living standards of those least able to provide for themselves.

PETITION.TITLE: Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is an urgent need to up-grade and extend the facilities at the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Provide the necessary capital funding for the Northern Rivers CAE to ensure North Coast students have access to a tertiary institution capable of providing them with the skills they will need to meet the challenges of the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully request that:
That world's resources be redirected to the relief of human suffering, starvation, poverty and disease.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Stop spending taxpayers money on self promotion through high cost high profile but superficial policy on nuclear disarmament and make a genuine bi-partisan commitment to positive and practical policies designed to achieve progressive world-wide nuclear disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
that the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
that consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
that unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia.

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e, set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia.
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair;
It will severely disadvantage both employees and employers;
Employees will clearly lose many fringe benefits as a direct result of the additional heavy taxation burden being imposed upon employers;
Employers will be forced to pay even higher levels of taxation to provide fringe benefits for employees.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to respond appropriately to Australia's trade crisis, the resultant record trade deficit and the consequent lowering of living standards for all Australians.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially I wish to draw the attention of the House to the important fact that the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) himself is not in the House. If he intends to respond to the debate I believe that he should be here to listen to the charges that are made against him.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians awaited last Tuesday's Budget for the Government's response to Australia's trade crisis. This occurred in a month when the Australian dollar had shrunk to a record low as a result of the current account deficit which continued its July plunge after a record of $13.7 billion which was adjusted to 1986. It is interesting to note that that figure was reached after the previous two records which had escalated from the previous years by $3,000m each. It also occurred at a time when our annual inflation rate was posted at 8.4 per cent and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had awarded a 2.3 per cent wage increase and a 3 per cent superannuation payment which the markets determined we did not deserve and could not afford. It was also at a time when interest rates had edged up to 18.5 per cent. The Budget itself gives no relief to the dollar which fell by another 4c as the international money markets gave their opinion of our trading prospects, our economy and-most importantly-this Government.

Australians have been asked, through this Budget, to sacrifice their standards of living. They have made that sacrifice, but no guarantee has been given by the Government and very little hope has been given in the Budget of improving Australia's balance of trade and its competitiveness as a result of the sacrifice. We might say that the Budget itself has been an instrument which has provided too little too late, because the Government became aware of the situation at least 12 months ago. Certainly the rest of Australia was aware of it at that time.

For the past six months the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) have been posturing overseas about corrupt trading practices engaged in in the European Economic Community and the United States of America. What the international markets have been saying for a while and particularly this week is that this Labor Government has corrupted the Australian domestic economy. The result is the decreased value of our dollar.

Probably the most recent debacle was highlighted in the Sydney Morning Herald today. For those who did not see it, it carried an article referring to a lost opportunity in the Philippines. This comes on the eve of a meeting of the agricultural exporting nations in Cairns. The Australian Government has offended the Philippines, which is to be a key participant in that meeting. The Philippines Minister for Agriculture and Food, Mr Ramon Mitra, is, according to my information, so annoyed by the Australian Government's procrastination over the appointment of an Australian scientist as a livestock consultant to his country, that he has reportedly placed an embargo on the importation of Australian livestock and products. According again to my information, Mr Mitra will not be attending the Cairns meeting, which is a rather important meeting, having earlier assured the Minister for Trade that he would do so. These responses are not surprising, given the Australian Government's procrastination over the consultant's appointment, which has held up all livestock development projects in the Philippines' completely neglected livestock sector. Apparently this matter has dragged on since early March, when the Minister for Foreign Affairs first gave an assurance to Mr Mitra that a particular Australian agricultural consultant would be appointed. This affair must be acutely embarrassing to the Minister for Trade, who is now at the table, as only a fortnight ago he was promoting the expression of interest from Mr Mitra in Australia as a source of supply for live cattle. It is also embarrassing to the Prime Minister, who is due to attend the meeting in Cairns on 26 and 27 August. Even so, it is infinitely worse for the Philippines which must be desperate to go to the lengths that it has to apply such an embargo in the current situation.

President Aquino has identified agriculture as a priority sector in the Philippines' reconstruction process and now, after all the Australian Government's protestations about wanting to help and trade with Manila, it has let the Filipinos down. The meeting of `fair traders' in Cairns next week is vital in establishing more liberalised world trade, but the Government's treatment of the Philippines could now overshadow that conference on the eve of its commencement. The Sydney Morning Herald article goes on to indicate that Mr Mitra has suggested that the trade that might have been ours will now be shared with the United States, France and New Zealand. That is one of the more up to date matters to which we can refer when we talk about this Government's neglect in that regard.

I wish to deal with the area of corruption with which the Minister for Trade seems so well acquainted when he talks about the EEC and the United States farm Bill. I mention particularly the United States farm Bill. As early as March 1985 the then shadow Minister for Trade, Mr Tom McVeigh, gave a warning that the Prime Minister should stand up for Australia and defend our interests over the United States farm Bill. That was in March 1985; it is now August 1986. About a year later the Minister for Trade went to the United States to talk about the United States farm Bill. What the Minister did not know was that a trade war was in the offing as he returned to Australia in Neville Chamberlain style, touting a letter of support from Congressman Kika de la Garza to the United States Administration. The Minister for Trade has claimed credit for cutting the Bill in half, from $2 billion to $1 billion. It later emerged that the export enhancement program was actually $1.5 billion. After the Prime Minister visited the United States, Australia lost a wheat sale to the Yemen and its barley, cotton and rice markets were placed under threat. The Minister for Primary Industry was next to visit the United States, with the result that the United States attacked our wheat market in Sri Lanka before the Minister had even left the country-and this after being given the warning by our shadow Minister for Trade, the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), so many months before that all was not right with the farm Bill.

This sequence of events prompted the response of the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). His response to the developing crisis was to call for an all-party delegation to be sent to the United States. The Government was also urged to request the United States Ambassador to attend Parliament House to respond in this regard. But it took the Government three weeks to act on this advice, and only then not until long after the news broke about the Dole amendment. The all-party delegation, which was suggested by the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, was successful, although it could not prevent the United States from selling 4 million tonnes of wheat to Russia. While all this was happening and while the all-party delegation was in the United States, the Prime Minister was in London prepared to give away Australia's $60m South African wheat market without knowing this could be the consequence of Australian sanctions on South Africa.

I refer to another recent trip by the Minister for Trade. Shortly afterwards the Minister led a joint business-union-government delegation to Japan to promote Australia's coal and iron ore exports. He took with him on this trip the President of the Western Australian mining unions, Mr Jack Marks. Only a week before he left, Mr Marks had threatened to use the opportunity to tell the Mitsui company, a part owner of the Robe River mining operations, that he would send it broke if it continued to buy iron ore from Robe River. Given this, he should never have been invited and I have been informed that he used that opportunity to embarrass the delegation. We have to ask at this time who paid Mr Marks's expenses in what was apparently an effort to sabotage Australia's trade? Was it the Government or the unions? This is all part of a response by this Government to Australia's critical balance of trade.

I refer now to the Budget. The Prime Minister, in his address to the nation in June, announced the small exporters scheme and the high technology exporters scheme. As a result of the Budget the new small exporters scheme is now redundant, the high technology exporters scheme has a minuscule budget of $1m and will help only a handful of high technology exporters, the mixed credit scheme operated by Austrade has had its budget reduced and the overall expenditure on export development schemes has declined massively to $92m-a move which will not enthuse exporters. During the last three years of coalition government export incentives averaged $267m. As a result of the Budget it is anticipated that Austrade will close its offices in Bahrain, Dubai and Kuwait. In this respect Australia's trade in the Middle East has been decreasing. It reached a peak of $115m in 1984 and amounted to just over $80m in 1985.

The Government's response is to close these Austrade offices at a time when the United States is very happy indeed to step into those markets. This was indicated in a report that suggested that a $200,000 study had been commissioned in the United States to seek market opportunities for United States sheep meat in the Middle East. Yet we are deserting those markets for others at a time of a national trade crisis. Also as a result of the Budget, the Government has lifted the ban on sales of uranium to France in order to sell its $66m stockpile. Ironically, this would make this socialist Government one of the biggest traders in yellowcake in the world. Yet still banned are exports of uranium to other countries. This is holding up exports from Australian mines such as Pancontinental's Jabiluka and Denison's Koongarra.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a double standard. They would not be guilty of that.
—Absolutely. It is a double standard and I think we all know of the tragic results over the last few years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was talking about the potential for uranium in Australia. The freezing of the reserves in Jabiluka and Koongarra is holding back an export potential of some billions of dollars. At a time when this trade is required we see the double standards of allowing some trade and not others. This uranium, worth some $40 billion could go a long way to redressing our imbalance of trade. It has been said that our most valuable export on the high seas is the export of uranium through Darwin. This great opportunity and the markets that are attached to it are being lost.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few months, with these appalling trade figures, the Labor Government's economic chickens have come home to roost. At a time of trade crisis Australia has been poised on the verge of industrial anarchy, our dollar has been in free-fall and the Government has had no obvious response. This is the result of Labor having misused the benefits of the international economic upturn, the breaking of the drought and the coalition's wage pause to embark on a public spending binge. Labor created one new public employee for every three in private enterprise but it lost 100,000 jobs in Australia's rural and mining sectors.

The Government has talked about the corruption in the international markets by the United States and the European Community but at home it has been corrupting domestic markets. Meanwhile, Labor's policies on capital taxation, interest rates and wages have been progressively making Australia uncompetitive compared with other international traders. Labor's recent fringe benefits tax and foreign tax credit schemes have exacerbated the situation for Australian traders. These measures, it has been suggested, represent the politics of envy and policies of hate against Australia's productive sector. The increase in taxation to a record high of 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product, the lack of cuts in government expenditure and programs and the rubbery growth figures contained in this week's Budget will be a constant restraint on Australia's export sector.

Last Tuesday all Australians were asked to make sacrifices, whether it was in pensions, more tax, a transfer of costs to them or a reduction in their standard of living. The productive sector has had to share in these sacrifices with additional fuel costs, the fringe benefits tax and the increase in taxation itself. With all this we have not had the guarantee of success in the Budget which should have been given by the Treasurer and as a result, all Australians are likely to suffer not just a temporary reduction but a permanent reduction in their living standards. This matter can be addressed only by the Government following the attitude that was taken last night by the Leader of the Opposition in calling for a new direction-a new direction on the industrial front, a new direction in public expenditure and a new direction in the tax reform system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a very spiteful and negative little speech from the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). Nowhere in that speech could I detect any suggestions as to the Opposition's alternative analysis of the problem that confronts us or, indeed, an alternative solution to the problem. Merely to round off the speech by saying that we ought to be following that deranged program which was presented to the House and the nation last night by the temporary Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), quite frankly, will not convince anybody that the honourable member for Dawson has any ideas about anything relating to the problems confronting our external account. This Government has been entirely frank about the problems confronting us. Some people would say that it has been too frank, but we think it is important to take into the nation's confidence the problems which confront us. They are extraordinarily serious problems. However, it is a question of whether or not one wants to make some sort of simplistic assessment that all of the problems confronting us externally are created by this Government. Of course, the narrow-minded view of the Opposition is that it would like to pretend that all of the problems, including the current account deficit problem we confront now and which we will confront for some time into the future, are the result of policies this Government has been pursuing.
—Nothing could be further from the truth.

—As the honourable member for Bendigo said, nothing could be further from the truth. In fact, this Government was pursuing economic policies which were entirely consistent with the circumstances confronting us when those policies were put into effect. What has happened, however, is that there has been a dramatic change in relation to what the world is prepared to pay us for the goods we export and the prices we are required to pay to the rest of the world for the goods we need in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the honourable member for Dawson to the handy little document entitled `Guide to the 1986-87 Commonwealth Budget'. Being a member of the National Party of Australia he would probably prefer to see it in pictorial rather than written form. Page 1 contains a very graphic drawing of what has been happening to our terms of trade over the last five or six years. If he looks at that, he will see that there has been an extraordinary decline from an index of 100 in 1983-84 to about 84 in 1985-86. That is a 16 per cent decline over a period of just over a couple of years. That is a dramatic decline. It is the case that over about the past 30 years there has been a gradual decline in Australia's terms of trade, but nothing like the collapse that has occurred in the past couple of years and, most spectacularly, in the last year. It does not matter what flights of fancy the honourable member for Dawson might have-he cannot under any circumstances whatsoever say that this Government is responsible for the prices the world is prepared to pay us for our agricultural commodities and the products of our mining industry. He cannot say that this is something that we have brought upon ourselves.

If we are going to go into the business of sheeting home blame to particular political parties in relation to our ability to cope with this problem, I would like to say that the totally inappropriate policies pursued by coalition governments over some 27 years were really the cause of the problem in terms of our response to this situation. They allowed our manufacturing industry to become increasingly uncompetitive and inefficient because of their mad-headed protectionist policies. They tried to cocoon Australian manufacturing industry to such an extent that it had regard only for the local, small Australian markets. They did not encourage industry to be competitive with the rest of the world and to look for the emerging marketing opportunities for their products in the rest of the world. Consequently, as a result of policies quite deliberately pursued and, as the honourable member for Dawson knows, quite deliberately advocated by former leaders of his Party, manufacturing industry has not been able to respond as quickly as we would have hoped to these current problems. That was all magnified and exacerbated by the high currency policies pursued by the current Leader of the Opposition. I do not intend to be lectured by the honourable member for Dawson or the Leader of the Opposition about appropriate policies for dealing with our external situation when they pursued policies for nearly 30 years which were totally inimical to Australia getting out of these problems by expanding its export base.

Other countries, which might be important agricultural and mining producers, have used the opportunities of the last 20 years or so, when the trade in manufactures was expanding, to diversify their trade. For instance, there was a time about 30 years ago when about 80 per cent of Canada's exports came from its mining and agricultural sectors. That is now down to 50 per cent, whereas in Australia the contribution made by mining and agriculture is still 80 per cent. Of course, it was our predecessors who ignored the opportunities and pursued totally wrong-headed policies in terms of trying to expand our manufactures and services industries and take advantage of the new and emerging trade opportunities for Australia in the region. Under the period of that Government our share of the regional and Japanese markets gradually declined. Our most important trading partner was being ignored by that Government which was totally oblivious to the changing relationship which was occurring between Australia, Japan and the rest of our region. What we have done and will continue to do is take a realistic view about our opportunities and the changes that will need to occur if Australia is to trade its way out of this problem, which the Government has accepted on many occasions is very serious and will not be turned around overnight.

The honourable member for Dawson spent some time referring to the low value of the Australian dollar. It was his Government's policy of artificially maintaining a high value of the Australian dollar which destroyed manufacturing industry and the incomes of the agricultural sector. It made exporting much harder and importing much more attractive. After years of maintaining the value of the Australian dollar at a high level, ostensibly for anti-inflationary policies, the whole basis and export capacity of our economy was massively distorted. Over the past three years we have been trying to correct the imbalances which were capriciously and deliberately pursued by our predecessors.

The honourable member for Dawson blithely overlooked the problems that are confronting the agricultural markets around the world. He blames us for the fact that the price of wheat has gone down from $140 a tonne not so long ago to about $80 a tonne. How on earth can he blame us for that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not blame you for it-I blamed you for the domestic economy.

—Of course the honourable member blamed us for that, because he failed to give us any proper analysis of the problem. All the honourable member could talk about was wages; he is completely obsessed by the question. In fact, if he were to look at our wages result and compare it with that of most of the other industrialised countries, he would see that we have been performing better than, or at least equal to, most of them. Our competitive position on wage costs has improved massively, not only as a result of the devaluation but also as a result of the substantially reduced real labour costs in this economy as a whole. As a result of the wages policy pursued by this Government, we now have real labour costs down to the level they were during the late 1960s before the wages explosions of the 1970s and the early 1980s when the Fraser Government decided to pursue its crazy policy of abandoning the centralised wage fixation system. In 1981-82 we had a 16 per cent increase in wages as a result of the policies pursued then-policies which the Opposition is now threatening to impose on the economy if it gets a chance to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been using our centralised wages system, which I accept is unique in the world, to work for us, not against us. We have been getting a better wages outcome than Britain and Japan and we are at least equal to that of the United States of America. Rather than tearing up our centralised system and leaving the nation to vagaries and total uncertainties, we have been able to make it work for us. The only certainty is that the Opposition policies were an absolute disaster when they were used before. It was a disaster from which we have been gradually recovering as a result of the policies of this Government.

The honourable member for Dawson, quite bereft of anything sensible to say, decided to focus on a couple of trivial issues in an attempt, quite deliberately, to sabotage the efforts which I have quite properly been making to streamline and improve our trading performance and the facilities that we provide to our exporters. He talks about the fact that Austrade decided to restructure some of its overseas posts, particularly in the Middle East. One of the major purposes of establishing Austrade was to give that organisation the capacity and flexibility to redefine where it should have its resources. Under the old arrangements, which were supported by our predecessors for however many years, if Austrade wanted to close a post it had to give up the resources, the money and the staff that went with it. It had to argue anew to the Department of Finance and to the Cabinet if it wanted to open a new post.

We have given Austrade the capacity to consider where its resources are deployed around the world. Everybody knows-in fairness, I suspect that even the honourable member for Dawson knows this, if he were prepared to say so-that we have had too many resources in some parts of the world, which have been frozen because it has been so hard to move them, and too few resources in markets that are really important to us. We have too many resources in Europe and North America and certainly too few in other regions.

Austrade has embarked upon a restructuring of its overseas posts, and what it has done in the Middle East is just the beginning of what it will be doing more substantially around the world. I commend Austrade on taking this action. It is important at a time when we have limited financial capacity to provide these very expensive posts overseas that the posts should be in the most strategically important places and in markets which are most prospective for us. We have not abandoned the Middle East. Instead, we have centralised the operation in the most prospective and most efficiently managed posts, which is the part of the Middle East which allows us most efficiently to manage our services in the area.

The honourable gentleman mentioned Jack Marks and his accompanying me to Japan. I do not know who told him that Jack Marks was an embarrassment. Whoever it was clearly does not share my view of the contribution which he made, or the view expressed by the delegation whilst we were there. There were four representatives of the coal industry and the iron ore industry who accompanied me, and the five of us signed a statement which talked about the importance of reliability of supply in terms of maintaining and expanding our markets in Japan. All of the four who accompanied me said that the exercise had been extremely worth while and that it was useful to have Jack Marks with us at the time that Peko-Wallsend Ltd was going on its mad adventure that was based on how it would restructure the Robe River operation. Jack Marks was able to explain to the Japanese partners in the Robe River operation the industrial relations realities in Australia and the contributions that the unions would be prepared to make to addressing the problems which Peko-Wallsend had identified. He was positive about that and helpful to Mitsui. Jack Marks and I met Mr Ejiri, the head of Mitsui, and we were able to explain matters. There is no doubt that Mitsui found it very useful to have that firsthand view of the situation.

Meanwhile, Jack Marks phoned back to the Pilbara to say that if the ships off Cape Lambert waiting to load from Robe River were not going to be able to load, they would be redirected to Port Hedland, where Mount Newman Mines could load them. That has now been agreed, and that will happen as a result of the co-operative approach of the unions and the leadership of Jack Marks. I have nothing but commendation for him in the role that he played in that exercise. I think that the other members of the delegation, if asked, would agree with that.

I had the opportunity to talk to Mr Mitra and we agreed about the great prospects for improving the trade in livestock. He never said that he would come to Cairns. He said that it was important that the Philippines should be represented, and it will be. If this is the problem for the Philippines, I shall take it up with the representatives of the Philippines. This question was not raised with me by Mr Mitra in the terms that the honourable member for Dawson has proposed.
