TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few things about the amendments which are before us and the Government's handling of this whole issue, which has been muddled, incompetent and evasive. The Government amendment, which was proposed in the Senate and is now amendment No. 3, was supposedly inserted as a result of an oversight. That is the amendment which allows one to read a class A document after the expiry of 30 years-a class A document, of course, does not concern Mr Justice Murphy in any way-so long as one has the written authority of the Presiding Officers. We made the point in detail that the purpose of a class A provision was to bury those documents. In the Senate, Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was an oversight in the drafting to leave it-
that is, clause 7-
completely open ended. It was not the intention really to do that forever. It was appropriate that archival rules apply, and an amendment relating to that has been circulated.

Archival rules do not apply, and in the drafting of the legislation it is impossible to see how that matter could have been misunderstood. I understand that Senator `It-seemed-Like-A-Good-Idea-At-The-Time' Evans was involved in the drafting. There was a meeting of the Legislative Committee on the Tuesday night and advisers from the Attorney-General's Department would have been there. The Attorney-General himself would have been there. Clause 7 (3) (a) as it stood was completely open-ended. I pointed that out in my speech in this House on Wednesday. I returned to it in Question Time on Thursday. I asked then:

Is there any precedent for providing by an Act of this Parliament that information before a commission of inquiry established by this Parliament . . . should be denied forever examination by the public . . .?

It cannot be said that the Government did not know what we were saying. It cannot be said that our criticisms were not clear or were not plain. When the Attorney-General answered my question he made no reference to the open-ended period. There was no reference to an oversight. When he answered my speech in the second reading debate, when he closed the debate on Wednesday, he said nothing about the criticisms that I have made about burial of material in perpetuity.

What has happened to change the Government's mind? There was no oversight. It is impossible for the Government and its advisers not to have understood what it was doing, incompetent though they have proved to be at every stage of this saga. The Government was reacting to an outcry by the media and a number of senior legal commentators. Its reaction is no more than characteristic of the Government's handling of the whole matter ever since this unfortunate series of events came before the House many months ago.

At this stage, I also point out that the Opposition said at the outset that section 72 should be given a wide interpretation. Senator Gareth Evans and the Government said no, that was quite wrong and that it should be given a narrow interpretation. The Opposition's views have been vindicated by the opinions of the three commissioners published yesterday. The Attorney- General, when he was speaking in this House, said-and I recall it with a certain irony:

I hope that for the first time the honourable member for North Sydney will at least read the legislation-it is there-and understand that the Commission would be able to do its duty, and perhaps would have done it in accordance with either section 18 or section 34.

He was there referring to some criticisms that I will come back to when we deal with the second matter, as to what would happen to material in the hands of the Government. I ask the question: Who failed to read the legislation? It is perfectly astonishing that such a simple Bill on such an important matter should be presented in such an extraordinarily incompetent manner, because not only was there a further amendment in the Senate, but we are today going to see even a further amendment to that Bill which was presented to me for the first time at 10 minutes past 12 today.

Having said that, there is nothing further we wish to say about these amendments. We do not intend to propose our own amendments again for the very good reason that they do not have the support, save in limited exceptions, of the Australian Democrats; so that would be a perfectly futile course. It is perfectly plain that even with the amendment that we now have, the material which is in the hands of the Commission, that is, that which has been generated within the Commission itself and which will be handed over, will be buried for a very long time indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the debate, but I just make the point that the significant part of the amendment which the honourable gentleman now agrees to provides that the appropriate documents that might fall within this category certainly will be under the archival limitation of 30 years which, of course, was one of the issues that were not really discussed. The issue at the time of the debate was whether they should be made available now. That was the Government's objection.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate's Amendment No. 4 be disagreed to, but that, in place thereof, clause 8 be omitted and the following clause substituted in the Bill:

``8. (1) A person shall not publish, or otherwise disclose to any other person, the whole or any part of a class A document that has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission, or counsel assisting the Commission.
Penalty:
(a) where the defendant is a natural person-$5,000 or imprisonment for 6 months, or both; or
(b) where the defendant is a corporation-$100,000.
``(2) Sub-section (1) does not apply in relation to anything done-
(a) in accordance with an authority given under sub-section 7 (4); or
(b) for the purposes of any proceedings for an offence against sub-section (1).
``(3) In this section, `class A document' has the same meaning as in section 7.''.

Briefly, the original clause 8, which has been objected to by the Senate, was an effort to prevent disclosure by any person relating to an allegation that might have been before the Commission. The Senate has amended that in a most unusual way by suggesting that any member of the Commission or any member of the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission who makes such disclosures shall be liable. It is very much like suggesting that one should shoot the gamekeeper instead of the poacher, because it means that everybody else will not be liable. I do not think even the members of the Opposition here today would agree that that was really the intention. The issue surely was what we want to do in terms of people who disclose material which there has been no opportunity to test by way of evidence, but which, of course, arose within the Commission. Let me make it very clear. In our view, the Senate Opposition amendment does not deal with the problem at all. I make the point that it attempts to punish the commissioners themselves, their staff or counsel assisting the Commission and nobody else.

The history of this matter is that there were unique terms of reference. Honourable members will recall that the inquiry was to be in camera and, in the light of the tragic developments concerning Mr Justice Murphy's health, about which medical evidence has now been tendered, allegations prepared in the Commission will never be tested. Indeed, the Commission has not at this stage, as far as the members of the Commission are concerned, even begun to examine whether they have any foundation at all. All that has happened is that a purely legal ruling has been made on the meaning of proved misbehaviour, which was the subject of counsel's submissions. As stated in the second reading speech it would be unconscionable and oppressive to allow any part of untested allegations prepared in the Commission to be circulated. It also would be, in the terms of the Commission itself, tantamount to hounding a dying person, and certainly a grave injustice to that person's family.

The amendment that the Government is now moving to clause 8 proposes to add a new sub-section (1) which will deal with the problem. I point out that the amendment is limited to documents that were prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission relating to conduct by Mr Justice Murphy. It does not apply to documents prepared by other persons that were received or obtained by the Commission. Any steps that persons who have supplied any information or document to the Commission wish to take to supply that information or document to other persons is also not covered. The amendment will eliminate the singling out of the members of the Commission, their staff and counsel as being the object at which the Senate's amendment is aimed. I want to make this a matter of record.

We have had advice from the Secretary of the Commission that all members of the Commission consider the Opposition's amendment-I know that it was moved in the Senate-as grossly offensive to persons associated with the Commission, and I can understand that. The Senate appears to have been misled by the Opposition into believing that the secrecy provision singling out members of the Commission had a precedent in Commonwealth legislation. There is no such precedent for this; it is totally wrong. The Royal Commissions Act has no such secrecy provision, contrary to what was submitted to the Senate. The very Act constituting the Commission itself contains no such provision. I just want to leave it at that.

One other matter that does concern me relates to this clause and the misinterpretation of it on the basis that there would be a coverup, that documents submitted to the Commission might never be able to be recovered or given to the appropriate law enforcement agencies. I again draw attention to the fact that the original legislation had provision, in sub-section 18 (2), for documents to be returned on request; and certainly the provisions under section 34 enabled the Commission to take action and give documents to other law enforcement agencies where there was some suggestion of criminal activity. All that has been dealt with. What we are about here is basically the allegations that might relate to conduct which have not been tested and could well be published, which could be most damaging, unfair and contrary to natural justice. That is the issue that we are anxious to project. Let me again endeavour to correct the Sydney Morning Herald which was anxious to refer to a Murphy coverup in an editorial on Thursday. The editorial said:
The bill to repeal that Act goes one step further. It prevents evidence given by a witness before the commission being used in any court proceedings, not just proceedings against the witness.

It is a matter of record that no evidence was given. It is also well known that any witness in the future can still do what he or she wants to do from the point of view of making allegations. I make this point and I hope that the newspaper corrects it: The record given to the Presiding Officers clearly shows that there was no evidence tendered by any witness. Having said that, there is no justification to suggest that there would be a coverup or that evidence given by a witness could not be given elsewhere. The real issue is that Mr Justice Murphy is dying, he has a very limited life expectancy and on that basis it is only fair and reasonable that allegations which there has been no opportunity to test or rebut should not be published.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) pointed out that the terms of reference here are unique and that there is no precedent for what we have before us. That is certainly so. The Attorney-General said that really it is offensive that there should be a provision which is directed towards the Commission and members of its staff. No offence was, of course, intended, but what the Attorney-General does not say is that the provision which is now before the Committee is in fact a provision which applies to the Commission, to the members of its staff and to everyone else. We sought to confine the operation of this extraordinary provision, bearing in mind that from the outset we opposed the inquiry being conducted in secret, to a narrow group of people. Of course we do not believe that the commissioners under any circumstances would improperly divulge information.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no parallel for this case, so it does not do the Attorney-General much good to refer to the Royal Commissions Act. If there is to be a secrecy provision at all in such a unique case, we must look to the material itself and ask: `How do we confine this?'.

If the Attorney-General wants analogies to people holding high positions in our system, one can go to the National Crime Authority Act, the Human Rights Commission Act, the Ombudsman Act, the National Companies and Securities Commission Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Government's own recent Australian Bill of Rights Bill and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill to see how persons holding high authority are brought within the confines of confidential or secrecy provisions. This Commission has been set up by the Government when forced to do so under extraordinary circumstances and with extraordinary terms of reference.

We have it that no evidence has been tendered. Therefore, the Government discards one of the provisions that it put into its own Bill, which is simply another mark of its incompetence. What the Government now proposes is perfectly astonishing. The Government's amendment states:

A person shall not publish, or otherwise disclose to any other person, the whole or any part of a class A document that has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission, or counsel assisting the Commission.

The effect of this amendment is to prohibit the publication or disclosure from one person to another of the whole or part of a class A document. Consequently, if the Commission has already passed to law enforcement agencies material prepared within the Commission in respect of which criminal action against third persons may arise, once this Bill becomes an Act, the persons in the law enforcement agencies who have received those documents will be prohibited from disclosing such documents to other police officers or publishing them for any other purposes. Effectively, if documents generated from within the Commission have been passed over to the law enforcement agency, and if those documents concern Mr Justice Murphy in any way at all-not just if they contain direct allegations against him, but so long as he is concerned in these documents-the police are straitjacketed.

Is it not perfectly ironic, therefore, that what is proposed in relation to Commission generated documents negates entirely anything that may have been done under section 34 of the Act and renders meaningless the assurance given yesterday by Senator Gareth Evans? He said:

So far as the Commission's capacity itself to pass on to law enforcement agencies material not originated from such agencies, but perhaps turning up in the course of documentary submissions made by other people, the Commission has the capacity under section 34 of the present Act to communicate such as it thinks appropriate of that material to law enforcement agencies.

Any documents compiled or prepared by the Commission and passed on to law enforcement agencies cannot be used as a consequence of this brilliant proposal from the Government. The problem posed by the Government's proposals do not arise under the Opposition's amendments, which were put up in the Senate and rejected. Those amendments provided for an orderly, thoughtful and timely examination and disposition of the material which, by our amendment to clause 8, which is now provided, would strictly confine the operation of the clause to those who were involved in the conduct of the Commission. To return to what the Attorney-General said about secrecy, we do not propose that the world at large be prohibited in the way that the Attorney-General does; we propose a provision confined simply to those who were involved. It is certainly not intended to be offensive to the Commission, no more than the provisions in the Acts to which I have referred are intended to be offensive to high officers who are caught by those provisions.

Let me say something about the question of cover-up which the Attorney-General has raised, and something about the conduct of the Commission and how the proposal before the House would affect matters. The work of the Commission was to obtain documents from various sources, to make its own investigations and inquiries, and to prepare its own documents, including summaries of relevant issues and events. In all probability, a vast bulk of documents has been accumulated, many generated within the Commission and by its own efforts. Senator Gareth Evans said:
I refer also to internal analysis of those allegations-
he was referring to the list of 14 already prepared-

and the cross-referencing of material, and the products of such investigation and information gathering as has been initiated or generated from within the Commission . . . I have no idea how much of that material exists but I am sure that by now, after several weeks of operation and the Commission having got to the stage of its report that it has, there is quite a bulk of that material.

That is material generated from within the Commission. We know that the material before the Commission was so great in bulk that it was estimated that four months would be taken up with the hearing of evidence in relation to allegations formulated in early August. We can assume that the material before the Commission may well have included fresh evidence and fresh information which, as well as concerning Mr Justice Murphy-I am not here concerned with him-may have quite separately concerned others, including those prominent in New South Wales politics. That evidence might relate to material already gathered and generated before the Commission. In sum, in all probability a large bulk of Commission generated information exists.

If the Commission can no longer send any of its own material to law enforcement officers, that is a great shackle upon what it can do. Worse, if this amendment is passed, the consequence will be that so far as the Commission has sent Commission generated material to law enforcement officers, they will be prohibited from using that material. It says:
A person shall not publish, or otherwise disclose to any other person, the whole or any part of a class A document . . .

I wish to make it plain that when I talk about Commission generated material, I mean that the prohibition under the Government's proposal relates to class A documents. But many class A documents generated within the Commission may well concern others as well as Mr Justice Murphy and may be directly relevant to law enforcement.

The Opposition was concerned to ensure that the Commission had adequate time and facilities to examine the material before it for a secondary purpose-that is, to refer relevant material to law enforcement authorities, as section 34 of the Act contemplated. It was also our concern to ensure that fair protection be given to Mr Justice Murphy against allegations that he had not had the opportunity to meet, hence the Archives Act proposal. We did not propose that any material be thrown out into the public forum. We proposed that it be dealt with properly and that material that was not sent to law enforcement agencies should be dealt with under the provisions of the Archives Act, but those amendments were rejected in the Senate by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly in reply, I want to make the point that the big issue we are concerned about is that of a man dying. Allegations having been prepared from within the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry itself, an effort has been made by the Government, in the interests of justice, to prevent those allegations being published because there has been no evidence to substantiate them and no opportunity to contradict them. It is acknowledged that there may well have been other documents given to the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point again that those documents would have been returned under section 18 (2) to anybody who so requests them. If the Commission obtained criminal intelligence that related to other matters, it would have passed the information on to any other law enforcement agency pursuant to section 34 of the original Act. So it follows that what the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) is about is going to happen, that there is going to be some suggestion of a criminal act which is going to be forever prevented from being able to be investigated. All those other agencies would have had and will have the opportunity to investigate any matter. It would also follow, I would think, that if there is criminal intelligence available to them now they will be carrying out their own investigations and, of course, will be able to accumulate whatever evidence is necessary. In this case we have before us the opportunity to do something to assist Mr Justice Murphy in his particular difficulty of being unable to answer allegations for which there has been no substantiation. Members of the Opposition have generally held the attitude that people who have served in Parliament should never be appointed to the High Court of Australia. This is a little bit unusual now. I do not know whether this is the view of the honourable member for North Sydney. Certainly it is the view of the Opposition as announced by the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair). I also think it is unfair to be continuing the media suggestion that there is a cover-up; there is no cover-up. The issue here developed in an unusual way from within the High Court itself. That is the position. There have been a series of trials; there has been an acquittal; and there has been a continual investigation of allegations for some 2 1/2 years. I do not want to delay the Committee any more, but the issue is one of whether there was something by way of misconduct.

The Government set up the Commission to advise the Parliament as to what might be misbehaviour. If honourable members read the recommendations from the commissioners, they will see that it will be left to future parliaments, in accordance with fairness, to determine such matters. So it will not be left to anybody outside. Perhaps a parliament of the future that is faced with a difficulty similar to that which we have been endeavouring to deal with here will at least deal with the evidence fairly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one thing that I want to make perfectly plain: The proposals that we put up to the Senate provided, as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) will understand, that insofar as material was not passed out to law enforcement agencies or returned to the National Crime Authority it should be dealt with in a particular way which would have prevented allegations against Mr Justice Murphy from being passed into the public arena. We did that because we thought it was fair to him to do just that. Nobody wants to have untested allegations concerning a man simply thrown out into the public arena, and especially a person who is in a state of grievous ill-health. What the Attorney-General has said is that all we are concerned about here is allegations. That is not what we are concerned about. What we are concerned about here is material that neither the Attorney-General nor I have seen-material which is called class A material, which is material that concerns Mr Justice Murphy. Let me quote the precise words in the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: `Class A document' means a document referred to in sub-section (1) that contains material relating to the conduct of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy;

It can also contain material relating to the conduct of others. The Attorney-General says that we are only dealing with allegations. We are not only dealing with allegations; we are also dealing with the Commission generated documents which would relate, in general terms, to Mr Justice Murphy because that was the charter that the Commission had. What we are concerned about is to ensure that they are properly disposed of, including being handed over to law enforcement agencies.

A couple of days ago the Attorney-General asked: `How can you cover-up when the Commission itself, having examined the documents, is entitled and able to give the documents to the appropriate law enforcement authority?'. I reiterate that the work of referral of matters relevant to criminal investigations was secondary to the prime task of the Commission; that anyone with the least practical experience in the conduct of investigations involving a vast bulk of material, such as the present one obviously does, would understand that the closest of analysis is required to pick out everything that may be relevant to the establishment of criminal offences; and that the amendments we proposed would have given the Commission the powers and the time to do whatever was necessary in the public interest to ensure that all material that may be relevant to criminal investigations was handed over to the appropriate law enforcement authorities. We do not know, nor can you, Mr Attorney-General, know the details of the matters being examined by the Commission. We do not know the nature of fresh material that the Commission may have unearthed, as Senator Evans's own statement, which I quoted a few minutes ago, simply confirms. But we do know, because Senator Evans has told us, that material received from persons outside law enforcement agencies is being returned. Senator Evans said:
No copies of that material are being kept.

By haste, by refusing to give the Commission adequate powers to dispose of all its material, as our amendments would have given it, the time to consider where the material should go and the time closely to analyse it, the Government runs the risk that material relevant to criminal investigations-and we know from Senator Evans's statement that some has already been referred, I understand, to law enforcement authorities-may be lost forever. This seems to be a risk that the Government is not only willing to take but seems eager to embrace.

The Attorney-General says that the Government set this Commission up. That is true. It set it up in response to a vast prompting and to a surge in public opinion. The Attorney-General established the Government's own inquiry. In section 34 the Government provided specifically that the Commission should have power to refer material to law enforcement agencies. I repeat that if one goes to section 34 one sees that the Government in its legislation has nominated law enforcement agencies, the Attorney-General's and others, as being the recipients of information and documents to which the Commission may refer for the prosecution or the possible prosecution of offenders.

I remind the Attorney-General once again that when he looks to the definition of a class A document he will see that it is a document that contains material relating to Mr Justice Murphy. So far as documents have been generated in the Commission which are class A documents and which also contain material relating to possible criminal offences by others, those documents, if they have been handed over to law enforcement agencies, cannot be published or otherwise disclosed by any person who has received them. That effectively means that the law enforcement agencies cannot use them.

The bumbling and the squalid handling by the Government of the whole issue over many months has been marked by an abdication throughout of constitutional responsibility and by a lack of understanding of the issues involved. The Opposition has never, at any time, persecuted Mr Justice Murphy. We have at all times upheld the Constitution and that is where the difference lies between the Government and the Opposition. I will conclude with a quotation from the Sydney Morning Herald which sums up this Government and the way in which it has gone about this whole matter over many months and years. The article states:

That is why the Federal Government's action, in one swift stroke, of terminating the inquiry and burying its remains will not be seen by history as simply an act of compassion and propriety to one man. It will be recognised as yet another attempt to delay the full examination of questions concerning the health of basic institutions-the courts and parliament-in NSW; questions which have demanded answers for almost three years since the NSW Police tapes first came to light.

Let us have no humbug about simple concern for the position of one man. We all have a concern for his position and for his health. But the Government has never had a concern worth a damn for the Constitution except when it was forced by public opinion to confront issues-but not until it was forced-and nor will it do it in the future because it is incapable of coming to grips with issues of constitutional principle if those issues may in any way be contrary to what the Government believes to be in its political interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it quite clear that, if there is any suggestion of any criminal activity anywhere else, that intelligence would have been already passed over pursuant to section 34 of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act and there would be no restriction or inhibition. Those law enforcement agencies can continue with that investigation. All other documents have been returned. What we are left with here is this extraordinary action. There is an attempt to suggest that there can be publication of allegations. The amendment moved in the Senate by the Opposition does nothing to prevent that. It is for that reason that we have to move this amendment-to protect the innocence of a man in respect of whom there has been no conviction, only allegations. I want to emphasise that. From a constitutional point of view, I just say to the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) that he had a remarkable change of heart between 29 April, when he said that he would not pursue the constitutional issue, and 8 May--
—That is not what I said and you know it. I have corrected you once and I will do it again. You should learn to read and to report what I do say.

—I have read into the record the fact that on 29 April the honourable member for North Sydney made a statement saying that he would not pursue that constitutional issue. On 8 May he had changed his mind.

—I am talking about any issue that the honourable member had in mind on 29 April-pursuant to section 72 of the Constitution, he said. On 8 May he changed his mind. He has the problem; we have not.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 5 of the National Museum of Australia Act 1980 provides for the establishment of a Gallery of Aboriginal Australia as a distinct but integral part of the National Museum.

In recognition of the importance of the Gallery of Aboriginal Australia, the Council of the National Museum at its second meeting established an Aboriginal Advisory Committee to advise the Council on the planning of the Gallery and all aspects of the Museum relating to Aboriginal people. Formed in 1984, the Aboriginal Advisory Committee has fifteen Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander members. Two of the members of the Committee are also members of the Council of the National Museum.

The Aboriginal Advisory Committee has advised the National Museum on an acquisitions policy, sacred/secret material, use of Aboriginal languages by the National Museum, the disposal of skeletal remains, exhibition policies for indoor and outdoor display and other relevant issues. Advice provided by the Aboriginal Advisory Committee has been adopted by the Council of the National Museum and incorporated into the planning of the institution.

The National Museum appointed a Curator of the Gallery of Aboriginal Australia in January 1985 together with support staff. Other positions in the National Museum have also been designated as suitable for staffing by Aboriginal people. When possible Aboriginals have filled these positions.

The National Museum is partly funding a two-year museum studies course for Aboriginal people at the Canberra College of Advanced Education. This course, leading to an Associate Diploma in Applied Science, is the only one of its kind in Australia. The course offers students broad training in museum policy and practice with particular reference to Aboriginal heritage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was Australia's position on the question of decolonisation of New Caledonia at the 1985 South Pacific Forum.

(2) Is he able to say (a) how the proposals of the Chirac Government differ from those of the Pisani-Fabius Plan in relation to movement in the direction of decolonisation, (b) whether they will lead to greater or lesser participation by the Melanesians in political decision-making in the territory.
(3) Is he able to say if these proposals will lead to a greater build-up of French military forces in the South Pacific; if so, of what magnitude.
(4) Is he able to say what the view of the French Socialist Party is regarding these changes.
(5) Is he able to say whether President Mitterand is able to have any influence over developments in New Caledonia.
(6) Will he explain the Government's view on the changes in French Government policy in the South Pacific.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia's position at the 1985 South Pacific Forum on the question of decolonisation of New Caledonia was reflected in the Communique agreed to by Heads of Government (including Australia) who attended the Forum, the relevant section of which reads as follows:
Decolonisation: New Caledonia
`The Forum reviewed developments in New Caledonia since its last meeting.

The Forum reaffirmed its suport for self-determination and the early transition to an independent New Caledonia in accordance with the innate, active rights and aspirations of the indigenous people and in a manner which guaranteed the rights and interests of all inhabitants of this multi-racial society.

The Forum condemned the violence which had and continues to occur in New Caledonia and which has resulted in tragic loss of life thus seriously jeopardising the process of dialogue. Heads of Government called on all parties to refrain from further violence and to engage in constructive dialogue which, alone, would ensure a peaceful and lasting resolution of New Caledonia's present problems.

Referring to the decision on New Caledonia adopted at its last meeting in Tuvalu, the Forum welcomed the fact that France had now publicly agreed to an early act of self-determination with the objective of bringing New Caledonia to independencee. The Forum noted with satisfaction that the date for the act of self-determination had been brought forward: the vote was now to take place by the end of 1987 at the latest.

The Forum urged the French Government to undertake electoral reforms before the act of self-determination to ensure that the result accurately reflected the wishes of the Kanak people and others who had a long-term residence in and commitment to New Caledonia.

The Forum noted with interest the statement made by the French Prime Minister in April 1985 in which he outlined proposals for the administration of New Caledonia in the period leading up to the act of self-determination. The Forum noted that, in accordance with the Prime Minister's announcement, legislation concerning the relationship between New Caledonia and France had recently been adopted by the Fench Parliament. Heads of Government expressed the view that the course of action on which the French Government had now embarked contained positive elements which were appropriate in assisting the territory in its evolution to independence. The Forum expressed the strong hope that this plan would be firmly and consistently pursued to its conclusion by 31 December 1987. The Forum called on all parties to work towards the proper conduct of the forthcoming regional elections in a fair and peaceful manner and to advance diligently the process of decolonisation within New Caledonia.

In the light of strong reservations about increased militarisation of the region, the Forum called on France to clarify publicly the nature and extent of its announced intention to upgrade its military facilities in New Caledonia. The Forum also again stressed its view that France should transfer additional political and administrative powers to the territory to ensure that it was adequately prepared for independence, and take the practical steps necessary to guarantee the full and active participation of the Melanesian community in the territory's educational, vocational, administrative and economic structures.

The Forum addressed the question of granting Forum observer status to the FLNKS and agreed to set up a working group to review the question of observer status in the Forum. The group should consider the existing guidelines governing the question of observer status, and consider whether any changes were desirable or necessary. The Forum noted that the work of this group would assist consideration of, but not be confined to, the proposal that the FLNKS be admitted to observer status at Forum meetings.

The Forum discussed in some detail the question of possible involvement of the United Nations in the situation in New Caledonia. It was widely acknowledged that keeping the question before the international community was important, and Forum members felt that speeches by Forum members in the United Nations General Assembly's general debate might take up the objectives of the Forum in relation to New Caledonia. However, the Forum reaffirmed that it had a continuing primary role, as a regional body, to continue its consideration of developments in the territory and to respond as and where appropriate. While noting the arguments on the question of reinscription at this juncture, the Forum would seek information from the appropriate organs of the UN on the applicability of the UN Charter and the 1960 Declaration on the granting of independence to colonial countries and peoples. It agreed to give further consideration to this question at its 17th meeting.

The Forum noted that the Ministerial Group established at Tuvalu to discuss Forum views on New Caledonia with the Independence Front and the French authorities had fulfilled its original mandate. It expressed appreciation for the reports circulated to all Forum members on the two meetings which members of the Ministerial Group had held at the end of 1984. The Forum agreed, however, that there was a need for all member countries to remain fully informed of developments in future and decided to establish a Standing Committee of officials to report to the Ministerial Group on a continuing basis over the crucial period before the next meeting of the Forum. The Officials Group should alert the Ministerial Group to any development including political developments in France itself which may call for a reaction or a response by the Ministerial Group or by Forum Governments as a whole.
The Forum agreed that its views should be conveyed formally to the French Government.

(2) (a) The Fabius Statute was introduced in August 1985 by the previous French Government of Prime Minister Fabius. The statute provided for a referendum to take place no later than 31 December 1987 for the people of New Caledonia to decide on accession to ``independence in association with France''. In the interim, four regions were created, a major plan of economic, social and cultural reform was to be put into effect, including the creation of a land reform office to return land held by settlers to traditional Kanak inhabitants, and steps were to be taken to strengthen the French military presence in New Caledonia.

The new French Government of Prime Minister Chirac which came into office in March 1986 has set aside the proposal for independence in association with France. This had been the key point of the Fabius Plan.

Transitional legislation promulgated on 19 July 1986 provides for an act of self-determination to take place within a year in which New Caledonians will be asked to choose between unqualified independence or continu- ation within the French Republic with a new statute based on autonomy and regionalisation. The conditions for the act of self-determination are to be set down in subsequent legislation and the main elements of the foreshadowed autonomy statute are to be communicated in advance.

Under the transitional legislation the reform ordinances introduced by the previous Government are abandoned, the financial powers at present held by the four regional councils-three of which are controlled by the pro-independence Kanak political movement, FLNKS-are transferred to the French High Commissioner and the land reform office is abolished.

(2) (b) The strengthening of the High Commissioner's powers, notably with respect to the regions over which he is to exercise a ``trusteeship'' authority, suggests that there will be less participation by the Melanesians in political decision-making in the territory in the interim period before the act of self-determination.

The outcome of the act of self-determination will determine the level of decision making by Melanesians. While the conditions for this act of self-determination are yet to be established, the Chirac Government has made it clear that it considers New Caledonia will remain part of France. The French Government has yet to spell out details of its autonomy/regionalisation proposal under which New Caledonia would remain part of France.

(4) There has been no authoritative statement of the French Socialist Party's views regarding these changes. The Socialist Party was, however, responsible for having amendments passed to the Government's draft legislation prior to its adoption by the National Assembly on 9 July. The Socialist Party declined to challenge the legislation after its adoption by the National Assembly and to refer it to the Constitutional Council, which is the ultimate arbiter of legal differences about legislation.

(5) Prior to the promulgation of the legislation, Presi- dent Mitterand had stated his ``deep concern'' and ``distress'' at measures which might ``create among the Melanesian population a sense of breach of undertakings given and hence of injustice''.

(6) Australia favours peaceful progress towards multiracial independence in New Caledonia. We are concerned that the Chirac Government's policy involves a disturbing move away from some of the positive measures introduced under the Fabius Government. Of particular concern is the apparent intention of the Chirac Government to maintain French rule in New Caledonia and the removal of powers which had been granted to the regions under the Fabius Plan. The Australian Government will continue to follow developments closely in New Caledonia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Do limitations of the Australian Taxation Office's (ATO) powers to investigate and obtain documentary evidence result in a lack of efficiency in the ATO's response to the challenges of organised and sophisticated tax fraud; if so, will he take steps to enact legislation strengthing the ATO's powers by bringing it into line with the provisions of section 545 of the Companies Code.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation advises that the information gathering powers contained in taxation legislation are used extensively by taxation investigators. Instances do occur, of course, where an investigation is protracted because the Commissioner's powers are contested. Generally, however, these powers are effective in achieving their purpose.
Fraudulent matters of the type that the honourable member mentions are often referred to the Australian Federal Police who may obtain a search warrant issued under the provisions of the Crimes Act.

The existing power of access to books, etc. that is provided by taxation legislation is similar to that provided by section 545 of the Companies Act. In terms of increased efficiency in investigating tax fraud, little could be gained from bringing the taxation provisions into line with the company law provisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to my question No. 1860 relating to the limitations on the Australian Taxation Office's (ATO) powers to investigate and obtain documentary evidence, will he take steps to introduce legislation strengthening the ATO's powers by bringing it into line with the provisions of section 203 of the Customs Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in answer to question No. 1860, the Commissioner of Taxation has advised that generally the information gathering powers contained in taxation legislation are effective in achieving their purpose.

I note that section 203 of the Customs Act mentioned in the honourable member's question permits certain authorised persons to seize certain goods in respect of which breaches of the Customs Act have occurred.
